The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p:
Aeneas was to≈ø≈øed with a like tempe≈øt, as Virgil finely de≈øcribeth it, Aeneid. 1. which place is well knowen to all yoong ≈øcholars. And the≈øe fre≈øh water ≈øouldiers di≈øcourage them≈øelues from trauell, and ≈øay, It was one of the three things which Cato repented, to trauell by Sea when hee might haue gone by Land: And a charge that Antigonus gaue his ≈øonnes (when they were to≈ø≈øed with a tempe≈øt) Remember (my ≈øonnes) and warne your po≈øterity of it, that they neuer hazard them≈øelues vpon ≈øuch aduentures. For Sailers and Aduenturers (as one ≈øaith very well) are neither among≈øt the liuing, nor among≈øt the dead: they hang betweene both, ready to offer vp their ≈øoules to euery flaw of wind and billow of water wherewith they are a≈ø≈øaulted, e≈øpecially to euery ≈øtormy wind, and huge ≈øea. And it is more ≈øafe (≈øay they) to ≈øtand vpon
the ≈øhoare, and to ≈øee the raging of the waters from the ≈øea bankes, than to be to≈ø≈øed thereupon, and endangered thereby.

Wherefore (albeit I be no great traueller my ≈øelfe) yet to ≈øet foorth the prai≈øe of the one, who haue beene at the co≈øt, hazarded the danger, and returned with credit; and to helpe the pu≈øillanimitie of others who feare to vndertake the trauell in regard of the danger; and to releeue the mi≈øerie of others, who are loth to bee at the co≈øt though they delight to heare and ≈øee ≈øtrange countries, people, and manners: I haue thought good to publi≈øh the trauels of others, which lately (by good chance) is come vnto my hands, after the death of Ma≈øter Bezaliell Biddulph a learned and religious gentleman, to whom they were fir≈øt written. In who≈øe ≈øtudy (among≈øt his letters and loo≈øe papers) was found fir≈øt of all a Copy of a voyage to Ieru≈øalem by Land, from Aleppo in Syria Comagena, not long ≈øince vndertaken and performed by fiue Engli≈øhmen there ≈øoiourning, viz Ma≈øter William Biddulph (Preacher to the Company of Engli≈øh Merchants re≈øident in Aleppo) Ma≈øter Ieffrey Kirbie Merchant, Ma≈øter Edward Abbot Merchant, Ma≈øter Iohn Elkin gentleman, and Ia≈øper Tyon Ieweller.

This vo ‚Ä¢ age was well penned, and generally well liked of all that ≈øaw it, who craued copies thereof, by which meanes at length it came to my hands: which I thorowly peru≈øing; and finding therein mention made of former Letters, concerning other voyages by one of the≈øe fiue trauellers formerly performed, directed to the ≈øaid Gentleman Bezaliel Biddulph: I could not ≈øatisfie my ≈øelfe vntill (by the meanes of friends) I came to the ≈øight of the re≈øt al≈øo, which were many in number, at lea≈øt
twenty letters, be≈øides the voyage to Ieru≈øalem, all directed vnto one man: Some by the Preacher aboue named, mai≈øter William Biddulph: and ≈øome by his brother Peter Biddulph Lapidarie and Diamond cutter in tho≈øe Countries. Out of all which Letters I haue gathered the matter therein contained, (leauing out onely ≈øome ≈øalutations and priuate matters) and haue thought good (for the helpe of Trauellers and delight of others) to make one body of them, and (without the con≈øent of either of them) to put them in print. For the one of the≈øe two brethren is yet beyond the Seas; the other (after ten yeeres trauell) is lately arriued into England, and hath ≈øundrie times beene reque≈øted (by diuers of his good friends) to publi≈øh his trauels, but he could neuer be per≈øwaded ≈øo to doe, but an≈øwered‚ñ™ that he knew how to ≈øpend his time better, and that he was not ignorant of the incredulitie of others in ≈øuch ca≈øes, who wil hardly beleeue any thing but that which they them≈øelues haue ≈øeene; and when they heare any thing that ≈øeemeth ≈øtrange vnto them, they reply, that trauellers may lie by authority: but they are liers them≈øelues which ≈øay ≈øo; for trauellers haue no more authority to lie than others, neither will they arrogate vnto them≈øelues more liberty to lie than others, e≈øpecially being men that feare God, as they (of all others) ≈øhould be, who goe downe to the Sea in ≈øhips, and ≈øee the workes of the Lord both by Sea and by Land, and his wonders in the deepe.

In regard whereof, hee hath beene ≈øo farre from printing his trauels, that he (being a very mode≈øt man) taketh no delight to ≈øpeake thereof, except it be vnto ≈øome familiar friend. But for that old acquaintance which I haue had with him (hauing beene his ≈øchollar) and that
mutuall loue betwixt vs of long continuance; I was ≈øo bold to make knowen vnto him, that I had ≈øeene all the letters which both he and his brother Peter Biddulph had written to their friend Bezaliel Biddulph, (wherein they di≈øcour≈øed of all their trauels) and what paines I had taken to gather them together for mine owne delight, and direction in my trauels, which I purpo≈øed ≈øhortly to vndertake. Whereupon he reque≈øted mee to keepe them ≈øecret to my ≈øelfe, which I told him I had done, fora≈ømuch as I had read in one of his letters to Mr. Bezaliel Biddulph, the like reque≈øt, which hee made vnto him in the≈øe words: I pray you keepe my Letters to your ≈øelfe, lest whiles to giue content vnto you in writing what you would, I receiue di≈øcontent my ≈øelfe in hearing what I would not.

Heereby I found him very affable, and willing to conferre with me of his trauels, and to giue me direction for mine, and to re≈øolue me in any thing I de≈øired, concealing my purpo≈øe of imprinting them, when (by conference with him and other trauellers into tho≈øe parts) I had perfected them. Yet, fora≈ømuch as a publike good is to be preferred before a priuate, I could not but impart vnto others that which I my ≈øelfe had learned of others: For that which Per≈øius ≈øpeaketh interrogatiuely, in this ca≈øe I vnder≈øtand po≈øitiuely:

div.p: And who knoweth what good may redounde vnto others, by reading of this di≈øcour≈øe of other Countries? For hereby all men may ≈øee how God hath ble≈ø≈øed our Countrie aboue others, and be ≈øtirred vp to thankefulne≈ø≈øe.
Hereby ≈øubiects may learne to loue, honour, and obey their good and gratious King, when they ≈øhall reade of the tyrannous gouernement of other Countries, and of the mercifull gouernement of theirs.

Heereby hearers may learne to loue and reuerence their Pa≈øtors, and to thank God for the ine≈øtimable benefit of the preaching of the word among≈øt them; when they ≈øhall reade in what blindne≈ø≈øe and palpable ignorance other nations liue, not knowing the right hand from the left in matters that concerne the kingdome of Heauen, and yet reuerence and honour their blind guids and ≈øuper≈øtitious Church-men like Angels, and prouide for their maintenance roially.

Heere wiues may learne to loue their husbands, when they ≈øhal read in what ≈ølauery women liue in other Contries, and in what awe and ≈øubiection to their husbands, and what libertie and freedome they them≈øelues enioy.

Heereby ≈øeruants may bee taught to be faithfull and dutifull to their Ma≈øters, when they ≈øhall read of the bruti≈øh and barbarous immanitie in other Countries of ma≈øters towards their ≈øeruants; who not only beat them like dogs, but ≈øell them at their plea≈øure, and ≈øometimes kill them for ≈ømall offences.

Heere rich men may learne to be thankefull to God, not onely for their libertie and freedome of their Con≈øcience and per≈øons; but of their goods al≈øo: when they ≈øhall read, how in other contries no man is ma≈øter of his
owne, but as the fatte≈øt oxe is neere≈øt vnto the ≈ølaughter, ≈øo the riche≈øt men are neere≈øt vnto death.

Here poore men may learne to be thankefull to God for their benefactors, and not to be repining and impatient beggers (as many of them are) when they ≈øhal read how in other countries the poore liue like brute bea≈øtes, on gra≈ø≈øe and water, the rich hauing no more mercie on them, then the rich glutton had of Lazarus.

Heere they that trauell in England may learne what a benefit it is to haue the refuge of Innes in their trauell, and bee content to pay well for it, where they are well v≈øed: wheras in other countries they lodge without dores all night and carie their proui≈øion with them.

And the publi≈øhing hereof without the Authors con≈øent may perhaps bee an inducement vnto him to enlarge this di≈øcour≈øe, by adding thereunto the diuer≈øities of Religions in tho≈øe countries, and what conference and di≈øputation he hath had with Iewes, Ie≈øuites, and people of ≈øundry other countries: and by perfiting any thing which herein ≈øhall be thought imperfect.

And yet I haue had conference with one of the Authors, and ≈øhewed his Letters vnto many other trauellers of good iudgement, who haue beene in tho≈øe parts, and all of them ≈øub≈øcribe vnto the trueth of euery thing therin contained. div.p:
Whereby I perceiued he tooke no plea≈øure to talke of it, and le≈ø≈øe to write of it. The rea≈øon, I vnder≈øtood by others; becau≈øe it was more dangerous, trouble≈øome, and tedious to him then all the re≈øt of his voiage: for manie nights they ≈ølept in the open fields, when it rained all night exceeding fa≈øt, and in the day time they were often
dangered by theeues, and oftentimes in the night they were glad to hire a guard to watch whiles they ≈ølept, for feare le≈øt their throats ≈øhould be cut whiles they were a≈øleepe: and many other mi≈øeries they were ≈øubiect vnto, as hunger and thir≈øt, heate in the day, cold (being harborles) in the night.

And be≈øides many mi≈øeries which hee hath indured by land; he hath very narrowly e≈øcaped many extreame dangers by Sea, whereof I will mention only one, which I haue heard, not only from his owne mouth (with gratefull memorie vnto God for his miraculous and vnexpected pre≈øeruation) but al≈øo from others who were in the ≈øame danger with him. In relation whereof they all agree in one, that it was on this manner.

Ann. Dom. 1605 Febr. 9. He, with ≈øome other Engli≈øhmen, viz. Samp≈øon Newport, and his brother Edward Newport, Edward Concke, Martin Kenti≈øh, William Welch, Thomas Mania ‚Ä¢ d, and others: hauing occa≈øion to trauell from Con≈øtantinople to Zante (for want of an Engli≈øh ≈øhip) imbarked theÃÑ≈øelues in a Raguzean ≈øhip which was bound thither. Wherein they ≈øailed ≈øafely, vntill they came among≈øt the Cyclades, or the 53. Iles in the Arches, where they were a while becalmed ouer again≈øt Milo, where they were minded to touch.

But ≈øuddenly this calme was turned to a ≈øtorme, which ≈øpeedily droue them out of the ≈øight of Milo, and Amimilo, and ≈øo confounded the Raguzean Mariners (being no skilfull Nauigators) that they knew not where they were, (an vncomfortable ca≈øe in ≈øuch a dangerous place, among≈øt ≈øo many Ilands ≈øo thicke together.) Before them they ≈øawe land in three places, yet none of them knew whether it were the maine land, or ≈øome Iland, and therfore
were ignorant what cour≈øe to take. The prouidence of God ≈øo directed, that they pa≈ø≈øed ≈øo neere the Ile Serigotta, as ≈øeldome or neuer any ≈øhip did, and not ru≈øh vpon the rockes.
When they were pa≈øt this Iland, they were out of the Arches or Cyclades, and had ≈øea-roome inough, which was ≈øome comfort.
But the ignorance of the Mariners, The violence of the ≈øtorme, The weaknes of the ≈øhip, and the prophanene≈ø≈øe of the company with whom he was ≈øhipped, were great cau≈øes of di≈øcomfort.

The Mariners were ignorant, not accu≈øtomed to ≈øaile by compas or cunding of the ≈øhip, but by the eie and view, and to be ≈øtill in ≈øight of land, The ≈øtorme ≈øtill increa≈øed more vehemently, and continued three daies and three nights together; during which time, they could neither eate nor drinke, nor ≈øleepe. The ≈øhip was weake and halfe full of water, ready to be ≈øplit in pieces with euery bla≈øt of wind, or to bee deuoured by euery waue of the Sea.

The boat which the ≈øhip towed after her, was cut off, and let goe at randome without hope of euer ≈øeeing it againe, le≈øt it ≈øhould be full of water, and ≈øinke, and draw the ≈øhip al≈øo vnder water. The companie as they were of diuers nations, ≈øo of diuers natures: and as they differed in religion, ≈øo likewi≈øe in their conuer≈øation and cariage, during the continuance of this tempe≈øt. For the ≈øtorme increa≈øed, the aire thundered, the winds blu≈øtered, the Sea raged, and the waues thereof ari≈øing like mightie mountaines, to≈ø≈øed vp the ≈øhip (to v≈øe the Poets Hyperbole) ≈øometimes as high as heauen, and by and by tumbled her downe againe as low as hell; ≈øo that (as the
P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øpeaketh, P≈øal. 107. 27.) They were to≈ø≈øed to and fro, and ≈øtaggered like drunken men, and all their cunning being gone, euery man called vpon his god (like the Mariners in Ionas ≈øhip.) The Raguzeans and Italians called vpon all the gods and godde≈ø≈øes, the Hee Saints, and She Saints, and ca≈øt Grand Benedicta into the ≈øea, to a≈ø≈øwage the madnes therof. Which nothing preuailing, the ma≈øter of the ≈øhip called ma≈øter Sam≈øon Newport (an Engli≈øh Merchant) and told him in Italian that hee vnder≈øtood that the Signior Reuerendo Dot ‚Ä¢ ore Ingle≈øe: that is, That the reuerend Engli≈øh Doctor (who was in his ≈øhip) had bin at Ieru≈øalem, and reque≈øted him to ≈øpeake vnto him, if he had any holy reliques in his che≈øt which hee brought from Ieru≈øalem, to giue him ≈øome to throw into the Sea, to pacifie the rage thereof. M. Newport made an≈øwer, that he knew that their Engli≈øh Preacher had no ≈øuch Reliques as he de≈øired.

Then there was nothing among≈øt the ≈øuper≈øtitious Papi≈øts, but weeping and wringing of hands; ≈øome preparing boards ready to ca≈øt them≈øelues into the Sea, looking at euery bla≈øt when the ≈øhip would bee di≈øiointed and ≈øhaken a≈øunder: Others pattering on beads, and making large vowes to Madonna de Lauretta, if ≈øhee would deliuer them; and to this Saint and that Saint, if they e≈øcaped.

The Ma≈øter of the ≈øhip, called Andrea, and his brother Stephano, (being both owners of the ≈øhip) ≈øaid, that ≈øurely the Engli≈øh Doctor was a Coniurer, for they neuer ≈øaw him without a booke in his hand, but ≈øtill reading, vntill (by his learning) he had rai≈øed a ≈øtorme vpon them; and thought it be≈øt to make a Ionas of him, and to ca≈øt both him and his books into the Sea: which they
had done indeed, if God (in mercy towards him) had not preuented them; for our Engli≈øhmen (like good Chri≈øtians) hauing learned out of the Scriptures (P≈øal. 46. 1.) That God is a pre ‚Ä¢ ent helpe in time of trouble, and hath promi≈øed to deliuer them that call vpon him in time of trouble, gaue them≈øelues both iointly and ≈øeuerally to praier, and all the time of this tempe≈øt cried vnto the Lord in their trouble, and he brought them out of their di≈øtre≈ø≈øe. He turned the ≈øtorme to calme, ≈øo that the waues thereof were ≈øtill. And ≈øo (at length) by the prouidence of God, they came all ≈øafely to their de≈øired Port, where they heard of many ≈øhips (as ≈øome reported, fiftie) which were ca≈øt away in that ≈øtorme, out of which they were deliuered. Many ≈øuch de≈øperate plunges hath he e≈øcaped in his ten yeeres trauell, which I haue heard of, but forbeare (for breuities ≈øake) to ≈øpeake of.

The≈øe things con≈øidered, I thought it not meet to pre≈ø≈øe him any further therewith, le≈øt the remembrance of former mi≈øeries, ≈øhould be a cau≈øe of fre≈øh ≈øorowes, knowing that he hath indured much hardne≈ø≈øe both by ≈øea and by land, & ≈øo much as may ≈øeeme admirable, yea, almo≈øt incredible that ≈øuch a ≈øpare leane man, and of ≈øuch a weake body (as he ≈øeemed to be of) ≈øhould endure in ten yeeres tedious trauell together. And yet notwith≈øtanding his continuall dangers both by ≈øea and by land, hee hath continued ≈øtill to preach the Go≈øpel con≈øtantly and boldly (in Heathen countries) both by ≈øea and by land; receiued great honour among≈øt them; and is now at length (by the prouidence of God) returned into his natiue countrie in health and ≈øafety to preach the Go≈øpell where≈øoeuer it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to call him: and is at this
day the greate≈øt traueller (of a man of his calling, that I know) in all England both by ≈øea and land.

By land, he hath trauelled further then Iacob, and the ≈øame way that Iacob did from Hebron to Padan Aram, and hath had as hard lodging in his trauell as Iacob had, viz. the ground to his bed, a ≈øtone for his pillow, the skie for his couering, and ≈øometimes the aire for his ≈øupper.
By Sea, farther then S. Paul, then Aeneas, or Vly≈ø≈øes haue done, and all the whole way that they all haue trauelled, and further.

Wherefore (gentle Reader) if thou take in good part the≈øe his trauels, and my paines and labour in collecting them together, it may perhaps encourage him to enlarge them, and me to procure them, and to adde thereunto his conference and di≈øputations with Iewes, Ie≈øuits, and ≈øundry other nations (which I vnder≈øtand hee hath had with them) and ≈øuch arguments as haue beene v≈øed on both ≈øides, & letters in ≈øundry languages which haue beene written on both ≈øides from one to another.

In the meane time, I leaue him (with his foure fellow trauellers) ≈øoiourning at the earthly Ieru≈øalem; and thee (gentle Reader) trauelling towards the heauenly Ieru≈øalem: where God grant at length we may all ariue, IESVS CHRIST being our Pilot and Ieni≈øary to conduct vs thereunto, AMEN.

closer.signed: Thine euer in the Lord, THEOPHILVS LAVENDER.

div.head: The Trauels of certaine Engli≈øh-men into Heathen Countries, ≈øet foorth by their Letters: the Contents whereof are heere ≈øet downe, as followeth. (*‚Åé*)

list.item: THe first Letter was written from Con≈øtantinople, the Primate and Metropolitan Citie in all Thracia, wherein the Author cert ‚Ä¢ fi ‚Ä¢ th his friend of his voyage from England thither, and of ≈øuch famous places, and memorable matters as he ≈øaw and ob≈øerued in the way thither. pag. 1.

II. The ≈øecond was ≈øeat from the ≈øame renowned Citie, wherein he de≈øcribeth Con≈øtantinople from the beginning hitherto, ≈øhewing the fir≈øt building, de≈øtruction, reedifying, and gouernment of the ≈øame vnto this pre≈øent day, and what Antiquities are to be ≈øeene therein pag. 17.

III. The third was written from Aleppo in Syria Comagena, wherein the Author mo≈øt iudiciou≈øly and learnedly di≈øcour≈øeth of his voyage from Con≈øtantinople thither; and de≈øcribeth both generally the whole Country of Syria, and particularly the City of Aleppo, the chiefe≈øt City (for trafficke) therein: and ≈øheweth, that Aleppo is inhabited by people of ≈øundry Countries; with the Religion, Gouernment, Manners, and Cu≈øtomes of euery Nation there dwelling or ≈øoiourning, which is of all the re≈øt mo≈øt plea≈øant to read, for the varietie of matters therein contained. pag. 31.

IIII. The fourth and la≈øt letter was written from Ieru≈øalem, wherein he maketh relation of his trauell by Land, together with foure other Engli≈øhmen, from the City of Aleppo in Syria Comagena, to Ieru≈øalem, by the Sea of Galile or Tyberias, and Lake of Genezareth, and ≈øo thorow the whole Land of Canaan, which way was neuer trauelled by any Engli≈øhman before, neither po≈ø≈øibly can be trauelled againe at this day, in regard of the turbulent and trouble≈øome e≈øtate of tho≈øe Countries, which is like euery day to grow wor≈øe rather than better. And this iourney may be called Iacobs iourney, becau≈øe all the whole way which they trauelled thither, is the way which Iacob trauelled from Bethel or Beer≈øhebah, to his vncle Labans hou≈øe at Padan Aram in Me≈øopotamia. pag. 86.

div.p: And this may ≈øerue partly for a Confirmation of M. Henry Tymberley his voyage from Grand Cayro in Egypt (formerly called Memphis) to Ieru≈øalem, performed the ≈øelfe ≈øame yeere, and at the ≈øelfe ≈øame time, for all of them met together at Ieru≈øalem.

And partly it may ≈øerue for a correction of ≈øome fal≈øe things therein contained, w ‚Ä¢ erein (being printed without his con≈øent) they haue done him wrong, as in the Preface to the Reader you may ≈øee plainly.

But chiefly it may ≈øerue for a direction to others who are minded heereafter to trauell into tho≈øe Orientall Countries, or East parts of the world, either to further them by the good directions heerein contained, or to hinder them in regard of the imminent dangers.

div.head: A LETTER SENT from Con≈øtantinople, to a learned Gentleman in England, wherein the Author di≈øcour≈øeth of his voiage from England thither, and of ≈øuch famous places, and memorable matters as hee ≈øaw in the way thither.
div.p: WOr≈øhipfull, and my worthy good friend, in mo≈øt kind and curteous manner I ≈øalute you: wi≈øhing vnto you all ioyes internall, externall, and Eternall. Being now (by the prouidence of God) after long and tedious trauell, arriued in ≈øafety at Con≈øtantinople: and calling to mind your continuall kindne≈ø≈øe towards me ≈øince our fir≈øt acquaintance, and your earne≈øt reque≈øt vnto me at my departure out of England, which was, to acquaint you with ≈øuch occurrences as in my voyage ≈øhould offer them≈øelues vnto my viewe; I could not without ≈øome note of ingratitude (which I would not willingly incur) refu≈øe to impart vnto you what memorable matters and famous places I haue ≈øeene and ob≈øerued in my voyage.

May it plea≈øe you therefore to vnder≈øtand, that after our departure from the coa≈øt of England, wee ≈øaw no land vntill wee came
neere vnto the coa≈øt of Spaine: and then appeared fir≈øt of all in ≈øight vnto vs a towne in Spaine called Territh or Tenerith, which was di≈øcerned fir≈øt by a red ≈øandy path on a mountaine neere vnto it. And ≈øhortly after, wee ≈øaw lubraltore on Europe ≈øide, and Abshi ‚Ä¢
(commonly called Ape hill) on Affrica ≈øide, betwixt which 2. places we entred in at the ≈øtraights mouth, with a ≈øwift currant and a good wind, commonly called the ≈øtraights of leubraltore, betwixt which place and Porungal, wee ≈øaw many Whales in the bay or G ‚Ä¢ lph of Portingal. And in three dayes ≈øailing from the ≈øtraights,Argier. we arriued at Argier in Barbary, where we ≈øtaied three daies, and were kindly intreated both by Ally Ba≈øhaw king of Argier, Ray≈øe, ≈øignifieth a Captaine. and al≈øo by Amurath Ray≈øe, commonly called Morat Ray≈øe. This citie is in forme like vnto a top-≈øaile, broad below, and narrow aboue. It is ≈øituated on the ≈øide of an hill, walled about, and a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle neere vnto the water ≈øide. It was fir≈øt called Me≈øgana, ≈øecondly, Iol, the royall ≈øeate of IVBA, the noble king of Mauritania. who in the time of the ciuil warre betwixt Cae≈øar and Pompey, valiantly defended Pompeyes part. By the Moores and Turkes at this day it is called Iezaier, but by the Spaniards it is called Algier. The people of this place, and the Spaniards are bitter enemies, and annoy one another oftentimes.

About 300. leagues from Argier wee ≈øaw Teddel, a citie in Affrica, and cape Bonne, which was formerly called Hyppo, where S. Augu≈øtine was Bi≈øhop, and Tunis, neere whereunto the ancient citie Carthage ≈øtood, built by Queene Dido, whereof ≈øome rumes are yet to bee ≈øeene.
Tunis is in Libia, and Morocus and Fe≈ø≈øe in Numidia.

About the≈øe parts we ≈øaw flying fi≈øhes,Flying Fi≈øhes. as big an Hearing, with two great ≈øinnes like vnto wings before, and two le≈ø≈øe behind; who being cha≈øed by Dolphines and Bonitaes, fly as long as their wings are wet, which is not farre, but oft agables length. Porpi≈øces and many other ≈øtrange and deformed fi≈øhes we ≈øaw in our voiage, the names whereof we knew not. We ≈øaw al≈øo ≈øword fi≈øhes and thre≈øhers: which two kind of fi≈øhes are deadly enemies vnto the Whale. The ≈øword fi≈øh ≈øwimmeth vnder him and pricketh him vp, and then the Thre≈øher, when hee hath him vp, belaboureth
him with his flayle or extraordinary long taile, and maketh him roare.

On the other ≈øide, ouer again≈øt Barbary in the Spani≈øh ≈øea, we ≈øaw two Iles called Baleares, which are al≈øo called Ma ‚Ä¢ orque Minorque, thirty miles di≈øtant the one from the other. And other 2. Iles in the Balearique ≈øea, called Ieuis & Ebu≈øus betweene Sardinia and Africa, the earth whereof will ≈øuffer no venemous thing to liue: we ≈øaw al≈øo an Ile called now Pantalarea, but of old it was called Paconia. It is very full of hils and rockes: there groweth great quantity of Cotton, Capers, Figs, Melons and Rei≈øings. The Iland is full of ce≈øternes. They ≈øay, that not onely the men of that Iland, but the women al≈øo are naturally good ≈øwimmers, but whether they be all ≈øo or not, I know not: but ≈øure I am, we ≈øaw one woman come ≈øwimming from thence to our ≈øhip (being becalmed) with a ba≈øket of fruite to ≈øell. The Ile is but thirtie miles in length, and ten miles in breadth.

The day following, we ≈øaw Sicilia, a famous Iland in the Tyrrhen ≈øea,Sicilia. 618. miles about. The Iland is mo≈øt plea≈øant, and no le≈ø≈øe fertile. In this Iland is Aetna, an high hill, burning continnally with brim≈øtone: it is now called Mons Gibelli; out of this hill ri≈øeth mo≈øt horrible ≈ømoake, and flames of fire, and ≈øometimes burning ≈øtones in great number. I haue heard that in this Ile there is a water whereinto if a dog be ca≈øt, he will die pre≈øently, but being taken out and ca≈øt into another water neere vnto it, he liueth againe, but this I haue not ≈øeene, and therefore referre it to others which haue ≈øeene it. Me≈ø≈øana, commonly called Mi≈ø≈øina, is the chiefe≈øt citie in Sicilie, neere the Promontory Pelorus. In the ≈øea n√©ere vnto this Iland, there is a dangerous rocke called Scylla, and ouer again≈øt this dangerous rocke, there is a gulfe of the ≈øea called Charibdis, commonly at this day called the Kirbies. It is a very dangerous place, by rea≈øon of ≈øtreames flowing contrary each to other. It is ouer again≈øt Scylla: Marriners which ≈øaile betwixt the≈øe two, are carefull to keepe an euen cour≈øe, le≈øt, whiles they ≈øeeke to ≈øhun the one, they ru≈øh vpon the other, according to that ver≈øe,

q.l: Incidit in Scyllam cupiens vitare Charib dim.

div.p: that is,

q.l: Seeking to auoid one danger, they fall into another.

div.p: And in the Terrhen ≈øea by Sicilie there is another Ile called Strongyle or Stromboly, which burneth in like ≈øort as Aetna doeth, it is ouer again≈øt Naples. Sicilia is 50. leagues in length, that is 150. miles, accounting three leagues to a mile.

Ouer again≈øt cape Pa≈ø≈øera (which is a marke for Marriners at the Ea≈øtward end of Sicilia) there is an Iland called Malta, Malta. where (vpon ≈øome occa≈øion) we touched. It is that Iland mentioned Act. 28. 1, 2. where the viper came on Pauls hand. It was then called Melita, but now Malta. The inhabitants were then Barbarians, yet ≈øhewed Paul no little kindne≈ø≈øe, for they kindled a fire, and receiued him and his companie, becau≈øe of the pre≈øent colde, &c. But now they are ≈øuch Barbarous people which inhabit it, that rather then they will receiue Paul and his companions (I mean Prote≈øtants or any good Chri≈øtians) to the fire in kindnes to warme them, they will rather in crueltie ca≈øt them into the fire to burne them. Then a viper came on Pauls hand, and hee ≈øhooke him off without hurt: but now there are ≈øo manie viperous people there, who v≈øe ≈øo ≈øtrict Inqui≈øtion when ≈øtrangers come, that it is impo≈ø≈øible for a good man to ≈øhake them off without harme either to his ≈øoule, if hee di≈ø≈øemble, Renegadoes of denying the faith. or to his body, if he profe≈ø≈øe the trueth. The inhabitants are Renegadoes and Bandidoes of ≈øundry nations, Bandidoes are bani≈øhed men e≈øpecially, Greekes, Italians, Spaniards, Moores and Maltezes: There are many Souldiers there, who are in pay vnder the Spaniards, and their Captaines are called Knights of Malta. The common ≈øort weare no other clothing (becau≈øe of the extreamitie of the heat) then a linnen or white ≈øhirt girded vnder their bre≈øts, and ouer the ≈øame a fine white woollen mantle, called by the Moores a Barnu≈øe. There are in this Iland 60. Ca≈øtles, & as many villages, all well inhabited. There groweth great ≈øtore of Cottons, Pomegranates, Cytrons, Orenges, Melons, and other exellent fruits; but for wheat & wine, they doe furni≈øh them≈øelues out of Sicilia.

Tripoly in Barbary is a City ≈øituated on the maine land, vpon the coa≈øt of the Mediterranian Sea. It was builded by the Romans, and afterward ≈øubdued by the Gothes, which po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the ≈øame vnto the time of Homer.

The next places of any note, which w√©e ≈øaw,Zephalonia. were two Ilands in Graecia, namely, Zephalonia and Zante, betwixt which two our Ship pa≈ø≈øed. Both of them are inhabited by Greekes, but gouerned by the Signiory of Venice, who every third y√©ere ≈øend Prouidores with other Officers to rule there. They are both very fruitfull Ilands, y√©elding great ≈øtore of currance, oliues, pomecitrons, oringes, and lemmons, but ≈ømall ≈øtore of corne, which they continually fetch from other Countries. If through extremity of wether, or danger of Pirates, or cur≈øares, corne be not duly brought vnto them, in ≈øhort time they are ready to fami≈øh.

Zephalonia was of old called Ithaca, where Vly≈ø≈øes the ≈øonne of Laertes was King, who excelled all other Greeks in eloquence and ≈øubtilty of wit. He is commended by ancient Writers, for a famous Traueller: but if he were liuing in the≈øe daies, his trauels would be counted nothing, in re≈øpect of the trauels of many other now liuing: for he trauelled but betwixt Venice and Egypt which is now a common voyage.

Zante, Zante‚ñ™ of old was called Zacynthus, it was ≈øomtimes a wooddy Ile in the ≈øea Ionium, on the We≈øt of Pelopone≈øus. But there is now very little wood in it. It is hilly round about, but the middle of it is a plaine and fruitfull valley, y√©elding great ≈øtore of Currance, which are brought from thence into England. The Greekes wonder what we v≈øe to doe with ≈øo many Currance, and a≈øke ≈øometimes whether we v≈øe to dye with them, or feed Hogges with them. They were a very poore kind of people, when our Engli≈øh Marchants v≈øed traffique there fir≈øt: but now they are growen rich and proud.

There is al≈øo a citie in that Ile called Zante by the name of the Iland, which citie was built by Zacynthus ≈øonne to Dardanus, who raigned there. We ≈øtaied ten dayes in the rode of this city before we could get Pratticke, that is: leaue to come among≈øt
them, or to v≈øe traffique with them, for their cu≈øtome is not to giue pre≈øent Pratticke vnto any ≈øtrangers, vnle≈ø≈øe they bring a letter of health from the place whence they come, which we had not. And therefore ≈øome of our companie who had bu≈øine≈ø≈øe there, we ≈øent to the Lazaretta, which is a place like vnto the pe≈øt hou≈øe in More-fields, where, though they be in health, yet there they mu≈øt ≈øtay ≈øo long as it plea≈øeth the Signiors of health, which is ≈øometime twenty, and ≈øometimes forty dayes: and in the meane time, if any of their companie fall ≈øicke, though it be at the end of fortie daies, yet mu≈øt they ≈øtay forty daies longer. So long as they are kept without Pratticke, they haue a Guardian ≈øet to watch them that they come into no companie, neither any man into theirs: yet may their friends come to vi≈øit them, and ≈øtanding farre off, may ≈øpeake with them, but if they come too neere them, the Guardian will cry out vnto them, Alargo, alargo, that is: Stand backe. And who≈øoeuer coÃÑmeth ≈øo n√©ere them as to touch them, loo≈øeth his owne Pratticke, and mu≈øt k√©epe them companie during their continuance there. If they bring any letters for any Merchants in the Citie, the GuardiaÃÑ wil open them & aire them at the fice before he wil deliuer them. But if the letter be ≈øowed (or if there bee any thread about them) they mu≈øt not be deliuered vntill they that brought them haue Prattick. And this they doe vnder pretence of auoiding ≈øickne≈ø≈øe: but they haue a further meaning therein, viz. partly to get money and bribes; and partly to bee acquainted with the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of all commers, and what commodities they bring. And who≈øoeuer pre≈øumeth to come on ≈øhoare without Pratticke, is in danger of hanging, or hauing the ≈øtrappado. And though they haue a certificate that there is health in the place from whence they came, yet mu≈øt they not come on ≈øhoare before they haue ≈øhewed their Fede, or Neate patent vnto three officers, called Signiors of health.

Zante is very much ≈øubiect vnto earthquakes. There is no yeere pa≈ø≈øeth without many earthquakes, e≈øpecially in the moneths of September and October, in which moneths I haue knowen two or three earthquakes in one weeke. In regard
whereof they build hou≈øes very lowe, le≈øt they ≈øhould bee ouerthrowen by earthquakes. And when they feele the earthquakes beginne (whether it be by day or by night) the Greekes v≈øe pre≈øently to ring their bels to ≈øtir vp the people unto Praier.

In Zante there is a very ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle ≈øtanding on an high hill, it is al≈øo very large, halfe as big as the Citie of Zante, and therein dwelleth the Prouidatore who gouerneth the Iland, and many other: and there is the place of iudgement where all cau≈øes both Criminall and Iudiciall are decided by the Prouidatore & his Coun≈øelliers: ouer which place the≈øe two Lattin ver≈øes are written on the walle in letters of gold.

q.l: Hic locus odit, amat, punit, con≈øeruat, honorat:
Nequitiam, pacem, crimina, iura, probos.

div.p: which may be Engli≈øhed thus,

q.l: This place doeth hate vnthrif ‚Ä¢ ines,
Loue peace, and puni≈øh wickednes;
Maintaineth right and equity,
And honoureth good men worthily.

div.p: Ouer again≈øt Zante is the maine land of Graecia, called now Morea, but of old Peloponne≈øus, almo≈øt enuironed with the ≈øea, hauing on the We≈øt and South, the ≈øea Adriaticum; on the ea≈øt the ≈øea of Creete: And in the middle of Peloponne≈øus is a Country called Arcadia, ≈øo called of Arcas ≈øonne to Jupiter by Cali≈øtho, who raigned there. Arcadia is famous for ≈øhepheards: There are great ≈øtore of ≈øh√©epe continually feeding, and good pa≈øture for them. In the narrow ≈øtrait, going into Peloponne≈øus, was Corinth, that famous City in Achaia, ≈øituated, but now vtterly de≈øtroied.

From Zante w√©e ≈øet ≈øaile towards Venice, and touched by the way at many places; and fir≈øt of all, at a Port n√©ere vnto Corphu, called Madonn ‚Ä¢ de Gazopo, where there is a Church dedicated vnto the Virgin Mary, whereunto there is great re≈øort of ≈øuch as haue e≈øcaped dangers by ≈øea, or ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, or other dangers by land, to offer ≈øomething to Madonna de Gazopo, for their deliuerance. And among≈øt many others, it was told vs by our con≈øort the ma≈øter of a Venice ≈øhip in our company, that
an Italian ≈øhip being in great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe by extremity of wether in the gulfe of Venice, when all hope of helpe by worldly meanes was pa≈øt, euery man fell to praier (like the Mariners in Ionas ≈øhip) and euery man called vpon his god, ≈øome to Neptune, ≈øome to S. Nicolas, ≈øome to one Saint, ≈øome to another: But the ma≈øter of the ≈øhip praied to Madonna de Gazopo, in this manner: O ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, deliuer me out of this danger, and J will offer vnto thee (if I come ≈øafely to Gazopo) a candle as bigge as the maine ma≈øte of my ≈øhip. Not much vnlike vnto another de≈øperate Mariner whom I haue heard of, who in a dangerous ≈øtorme, ≈ø√©eing euery man fall to his praiers, and prepare them≈øelues to die, he fell on his kn√©es, and praied in this manner: O Lord, I am no common begger; I doe not trouble thee euery day; for I neuer praied to thee before; and if it plea≈øe thee to deliuer me this once, I will neuer pray to thee againe as long as I liue. From Madonna de Gazopo we ≈øailed along by Albania, and were driuen with a cro≈ø≈øe winde to Ottronto in Calabria, at the entrance into the gulfe of Venice, where we ≈øtaied two daies. From thence we ≈øailed along the Illyrian ≈øhoare in the gulph of Venice, and came to an hauen towne in I≈øtria called Rauina ouer again≈øt Rauenna on the coa≈øt of Calabria: which Rauenna is an ancient Citie in Italy, by the Adri ‚Ä¢ tticke Sea. From Rauina in one dayes ≈øayling we arriued at Leo n√©ere vnto Venice, Venice. which is a mo≈øt famous Citie, ≈øo well knowen vnto all men by report, that I n√©ed not to ≈øpend any time in de≈øcribing it, le≈øt I ≈øhould rather ob≈øcure it, then any way (by my barren ≈øtile) illu≈øtrate the ≈øame, onely this I note, that there is both a countrey called Venetia, and a Citie called al≈øo by the ≈øame name.

From thence w√©e ≈øailed along in ≈øight of the maine land of Graecia, which among≈øt all other Countries in Europe, hath b√©ene accounted the mo≈øt noble and mo≈øt famous. After we came as high as the Iland Creta, which is now called Candie, we left the way towards Egypt, and entred into

In certaine villages of this Iland, the country people doe f√©ed them by great flocks, driuing them in the day time to gra≈øe in the mountaines; and towards night, the boyes or girles (which doe k√©epe them) doe call them together by a whi≈øtle or ≈øong. This Iland is one of the ≈øeuen which contended for Homers birth. And they ≈øay that Homer was buried in this Iland, and that his ≈øepulcher is to be ≈ø√©ene to this day vpon the Mount Helias, within an old Ca≈øtle in this Iland, but I haue not ≈ø√©ene it.

The maine land of A≈øia is in ≈øight ouer again≈øt Chios, and therein Smyrna, Ephe≈øus, and Thyatira, called now Tyria, with the re≈øt of the ≈øeuen Churches of A≈øia, to whom S. After we had ≈øtaied ten daies in Chios, which (as I haue ≈øaid) is now vulgarly called Sio or Scio, we ≈øailed towards Con≈øtantinople, by Mitilene an Iland in the Aegean ≈øea. This Mytilenes was formerly called Bythinia, which is a Country in A≈øia, oppo≈øite to Thracia, n√©ere Troy. div.p: The be≈øt and mo≈øt excellent wines in all Graecia are made at Chios and Tenedos. There is al≈øo a City in the ≈øame Ile called Tenedos, built by Tenes. In this Iland was the Temple of Neptune.
Ouer again≈øt Tenedos is Troy, which is al≈øo called Troas or Troada, Troy. whereof I can ≈øpeake no more but this that hath b√©ene long ≈øince written:

div.p: The Sea betw√©ene Moeotis and Tenedos is called Pontus.

A little beyond Troy, we entered the ≈øtrait of Helle≈øpont, which is a narrow ≈øea, called Helle≈øpontus, of Helle. It lieth betw√©ene the Aegean Sea and Propontis, and parteth Europe from A≈øia, It is not now called by the name of Helle≈øpont, but it is called now The Ca≈øtles; for there are ≈øtill two Ca≈øtles, which were of old called Se≈øtos and Abydos, one on the one ≈øide of the Heli≈øpont, the other on the other ≈øide, erected in memory of the loue of Leander and Hera, ouer which narrow ≈øea he often ≈øwomme vnto her, and was in the end drowned. The riuer Scamander runneth by the Ca≈øtles.

Mayto is ≈øtill a towne ouer again≈øt Abydos, Mayto. but on the ≈øame ≈øide as Se≈øte. There is made great ≈øtore of good wine, which is red in colour, & in ta≈øte like claret wine and ≈øugar, and yet they put no ≈øugar into it, for it is plea≈øant of it ≈øelfe. H√©ere our Merchants ≈øhips v≈øually take in wine for their proui≈øion. There
are very many wind milles there, hauing ten wings a piece.

The ≈øtrength of Con≈øtantinople con≈øi≈øtet chiefly in the≈øe two Ca≈øtles; for the≈øe Ca≈øtles are well fortified with munition, and are to examine all ≈øhippes that pa≈ø≈øe by, from whence they came, and whither they would: and there they are to pay a tribute to the King. If any Ships refu≈øe to ≈øtay from the Ca≈øtles, they will ≈øhoote them through. But if the≈øe Ca≈øtles were battered down, Con≈øtantinople and all the countrey thereabouts might be ea≈øily wonne. Notwith≈øtanding, the≈øe Ca≈øtles, a ≈ømall flight to k√©epe the narrow ≈øeas betwixt Chios and the Ca≈øtles, might in ≈øhort time fami≈øh all that countrey, for the greate≈øt part of their proui≈øion, for Rice and other Corne, commeth from Alexandria, and tho≈øe parts, with the Gazenda of the great Turk: but I leaue this to martiall men, and marriners.

Gallipolis is a great & ancient Citie 20. miles di≈øtant from the Ca≈øtles (which are at this day called the Ca≈øtles of Gallipoly, in the way to Con≈øtantinople ≈øituated vpon Cherenes of Thracia, at the point which looketh towards Propontis, which is all the ≈øea from the ≈øtraites of Helle≈øpont to Bo≈øphorus Thraicus. Some hold opinion that it was built by Caius Caligula. And others ≈øay that it was in times pa≈øt inhabited by French men, for that this word Gallipoly‚ñ™ ≈øignifieth the Citie of the Gaules or Frenchmen, and for that the French men do dwell in Gaule, as Nicopolis and Phillipopolis ≈øignifie the City of Nicolas and Philip.

Not far from Gallipoly was that famous City Nice, where the Generall Councell was held in Bythinia. And n√©ere vnto Con≈øtantinople is C ‚Ä¢ alcedon or Chalcedonia ouer again≈øt Byzantium, which was a famous City in Bythinia, where another Generall Councell was held. But it is now no City, but onely a plaine field, hauing h√©ere and there an hou≈øe yet ≈øtanding. At the point of Chalcedon we fir≈øt beheld the pro≈øpect of Con≈øtan ‚Ä¢ inople. Con≈øtantinople. which is mo≈øt plea≈øant to behold, being like vnto a City in a wood, or a wood in a City, hauing firre tr√©es, Cyprus tr√©es, and other plea≈øant tr√©es in gardens adioining to their hou≈øes. It is al≈øo adorned with many ≈øtately Towers, Churches,
and high St√©eples. The forme of the City is like vnto a Triangle, whereof two ≈øquares are by the water ≈øide, the other adioineth to the Land. After our Ship had ≈øaluted the Port, we went ouer to the other ≈øide, and anchored at Fundac ‚Ä¢ ee, and went on ≈øhore at Gallata, to ≈øalute the honourable Sir Henrie Lello, Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour for Qu√©ene Elizabeth of famous memorie, and to vi≈øit our Engli≈øh Merchants re≈øident there.

Our ≈øhip hauing di≈øcharged her goods at Fundacle, remoued from thence, and anchored further from ≈øhoare, betwixt Tapanau and Bezeta≈øh, expecting a good winde to depart. Con≈øtantiople is on the other ≈øide the water in Thracia, which is al≈øo called the countrey Romania in Europe, hauing on the we≈øt, Macedonia, on the North, I≈øther, on the Ea≈øt, Pontus, on the South, the Sea Aegeum.

As yet, I haue not beene farre in Con≈øtantinople, wherefore I forbeare to write any thing thereof at this time, purpo≈øing hereafter when I haue thorowly viewed it, to de≈øcribe it vnto you at large. In this Interim I humbly take my leaue, and leaue you to him, who neuer leaueth his.

div.p: SInce the writing of my former letters, I hauing often beene at Con≈øtantinople, and thorowly viewed the ≈øame, according to promi≈øe, I haue thought good to write ≈øomthing vnto you thereof.

May it plea≈øe you therefore to vnder≈øtand, that Con≈øtantinopolis is a Citie in Thracia, ≈øo called of Con≈øtantine the Emperour, becau≈øe hee enlarged the ≈øame. It was before called Byzantium. Strabo entituled it Illu≈øtre, and Plinie & Iu≈øtine called it mo≈øt Noble, being one of the mo≈øt fertile in all Europe. It is ≈øituted in Thracia, vpon the gulph Ponthus, which ≈øeparateth A≈øia from Europe. The forme thereof is thr√©e ≈øquare, whereof the two ≈øides are wa≈øhed by the ≈øea, & the third ioyneth vnto the firme land. The ≈øoile thereof is very delectable, bringing foorth all kindes of good fruites, nece≈ø≈øarie for ≈øu≈øtenance of humane life. The ≈øituation thereof is ≈øo well deui≈øed and ordered, that no Ship can enter, nor goe foorth but with leaue from the head Vizeir: for the Turke is ma≈øter of the Sea Pontike, which hauing 2. mouths, the one comming from Propontidis, and the other from the Sea Euxinum, (which is the Blacke ≈øea) is by Ouid called the Port of two Seas, for the di≈øtance from Con≈øtantinople to Calcedon is but 14. furlongs. And the place which by the ancients is called Phane, ≈øituated in A≈øia (whereas Ja≈øon returning from Calchos

But for as much as many great riuers of A≈øia, & many more of Europe, doe fall into the Euxine ≈øea, commonly called the blacke ≈øea; it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe, that being full, ≈øhee gu≈øheth out through the mouth of her with great violence, into the ≈øea Pontique, and from thence through the ≈øtraight of Helle≈øpont (being not much broader then thr√©e furlongs) into the Aegean Sea.

was fir≈øt builded by the Lacedemonians vnder the conduct of their Captaine Pau≈øanias, which was about the yeere of the world 3292. and before the birth of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt 663. yeeres; which, after they had con≈øulted with Apollo, where they ≈øhould plant and ≈øettle their abode and dwelling place, they were by an oracle an≈øwered, that they ≈øhould doe it, euen hard by the blind,Why the Me garians are called blind. which were the Megarians, for that, after they were ≈øailed into Thracia, leauing the good and fruitfull coa≈øt (where ≈øince Byzantium was builded) vnadui≈øedly went and planted them≈øelues, (either for y‚Ä¢ oppo≈øition) in the mo≈øt fruitful ground of A≈øia, or for the vain hope they had for the fi≈øhing; they builded there a Citie, which was called Calcedon. But they found them≈øelues greatly deceiued. Calcedon was builded by the Megarians. For, the fi≈øhes being caried by the violence of the floud and tide of the Euxine Sea into Propontis, approaching n√©ere vnto the Banks of Calcedon, being afraid, through the whitene≈ø≈øe of the rockes, doe retire ≈øtraight waies to the ≈øide of Bizantium, which gaue occa≈øion vnto the valiant Paulanias, to fortifie the Citie with good walles & rampiers, changing the fir≈øt name thereof, which as Plinie ≈øaith, was Ligos, and called the ≈øame Bizantium.

Notwith≈øtanding, Diodorus & Polybius doe contrarily ≈øay, that it was called Byzantium, by the name of a Captaine, which was the fir≈øt founder thereof. Pau≈øanias (as Zonoras writeth) po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the ≈øame ≈øeuen y√©eres: during which time, (Fortune ≈øhewing her ≈øelfe an enemie vnto his magnificence) ≈øtuffed the hearts of the Athenians with ≈øuch an in≈øatiable ambition, that they hauing brought thither their forces, after a long ≈øiege, and diuers a≈ø≈øaults, did beare away the victorie, which the Lacede
monians ≈øeeing could not abide, but with their whole pui≈ø≈øance tooke their weapons in hand with ≈øuch pertinacy, that the aduenture thereof on the one ≈øide and on the other, was very dangereous and variable. And being ≈øometimes taken againe by her fir≈øt founders, and afterwards by her aggre≈ø≈øors, became in the end a pray vnto both the armies. Byzanti ‚Ä¢ m ruined by Seuerus the Emperour. And after that, Seuerus ≈øucceeding in the R ‚Ä¢ mane Empire, the tyrant Pi≈ø≈øininus, her mortal enemie being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, Byzantium ≈øuborned the Emperour to lay ≈øiege vnto the ≈øame: who, not hauing ≈øufficient power to ouercome the ≈øame by a≈ø≈øaults, kept them be≈øieged the ≈øpace of three whole y√©eres, & in the end, through extreame famine, con≈øtained them to y√©eld them≈øelues vnto the mercy of the Romanes, which was ≈øuch, that after they had put to the ≈øword all the men of warre that were within it, and killed the Maie≈øtrates thereof, ruined and ca≈øt downe to the ground the walles of the Citie: and Seuerus afterwards (to ≈øati≈øfie his crueltie) ≈øpoiled the Citizens of all their rights, franchi≈øes and liberties; giuing moreouer the Land and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions vnto the Perinthians. And thus, this mo≈øt famous Citie remained in mi≈øerable calamitie, vntill ≈øuch time as Con≈øtantine the great Emperour remouing from Rome, did r√©edifie the ≈øame.

But before I write any thing of the reedifyigns of Byzantium The cau≈øe wherefore Con≈øtantine remooued from Rome. of Con≈øtantine the great: giue mee leaue to ≈øhew you the cau≈øe wherefore Con≈øtantine remoued from Rome.

2. The≈ø≈øal. 2. 7. S. Paul prophe≈øying of the reuealing of Antichri≈øt, ≈øaith thus: Yee know what withholdeth that he might be reuealed in his time, &c. Which hinderance was the Romane Emperous, which were fir≈øt to depart from Rome, and giue place to the Popes, becau≈øe, both Emperours and Popes could not raigne together in one Citie. And that hinderance was taken away long ≈øince, when Con≈øtantine the great tran≈ølated his imperiall Seat to Con≈øtantinople, and indowed the Popes with the Citie of Rome, and a great part of Italy lying about it.

The Emperours then being farre off, and (by rea≈øon of continuall warres with Saracens and enemies in the Ea≈øt) notable to maintaine their own right in the We≈øt, the Popes incroached vpon them too far, and v≈øurped ≈øo much authoritie, that they
di≈øcarded them cleane in Italy, and at their plea≈øure ≈øet vp other Emperours in the We≈øt, but ≈øuch as would take an oath to b√©e ≈øubiect to the Apo≈øtolike S√©e of Rome, and acknowledge the Popes to be vniuer≈øall Bi≈øhops. So the hinderance was taken away when Con≈øtantine remooued to Con≈øtantinople, and Antichri≈øt was manife≈øtly di≈øclo≈øed not long after when Boniface the third obtained the title of Vniuer≈øall Bi≈øhop, which was 900. y√©eres agoe, for (as Gregorie ≈øaith) none but Antichri≈øt would a≈ø≈øume vnto him ≈øuch a title.

But yet Con≈øtantine had no regard to any prophecie, when h√©e remooued at fir≈øt from Rome to Byzantium, and there ≈øetled his Emperiall pallace: but he re≈øpected onely a more commodious gouernement of tho≈øe matters and kingdomes of his that lay Ea≈øtward, which at that time were mi≈øerably di≈øquieted by the Parthians and Per≈øians. For Con≈øtantinople did ≈ø√©em to be ≈øo ≈øituated (whereas otherwi≈øe Con≈øtantine had once thought to haue ≈øetled el≈øewhere) as that it was (as you would ≈øay,) the nauel or midde≈øt vnto the whole Romane iuri≈ødiction, which, as we know, ≈øpread it ≈øelfe farre and n√©ere: and yet it could not po≈ø≈øibly otherwi≈øe fall out, becau≈øe that ≈øo the Romane Empire might become double headed, & haue tho≈øe two horns which God before had reuealed. So the prouidence of God guided this whole enterpri≈øe of Con≈øtantine, and ≈øo fulfilled what him≈øelfe had decr√©ed.
Hereby you may perceiue two cau≈øes wherefore Con≈øtantine remoued from Rome.
1. The fir≈øt more ≈øecret in the prouidence of God, that the prophecie of the Apo≈øtle Paul, 2. The≈ø≈øal. 2‚ñ™ 7. might be fulfilled.

2. The ≈øecond more publike and better knowen to all, viz. that Con≈øtantine the great Emperour of the Romanes, ≈ø√©eking to re≈øi≈øt the cour≈øes and robberies which the Parthes daily v≈øed towards the Romanes, deliberated to tran≈øport the Empyre into the Ea≈øt parts, and there to build a large Citie: which fir≈øt hee minded to haue builded in Sardique, and afterwards in Troyada a countrey of high Pmygia n√©ere vnto the cape Sige ‚Ä¢ , in the place where ≈øometime ≈øtood the Citie of Troy, which he began to reedifie, and to repaire the foundations thereof. But being by a
Reuelation in the night in≈øpired to change the place, cau≈øed to be recommenced the workes of Calcedon, where certaine Eagles (as Zo ‚Ä¢ arus writeth) being flowen thither, tooke in their bils the ma≈øons lines, and cro≈ø≈øing the ≈øtr√©ete, let them fall neere vnto Byzantium‚ñ™ whereof the Emperour being aduerti≈øed, taking the ≈øame for a good ≈øigne and diuine in≈øtruction, after hee had taken view of the place, called backe the ma≈øters of his workes from Calcedon, cau≈øed the City to be repaired and amplifyed, which, according to his name, he called Con≈øtantinople, notwith≈øtanding that at the fir≈øt he had called the ≈øame new Rome. Whereupon it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that both in generall Coun≈øels, and in the decr√©es of Emperours, mention is made of two Romes: one, the olde, which is the true Rome, built by Romulus; the other, the new, which is Con≈øtantinople, which al≈øo began to hold vp the head, by vertue of the priuiledges and prerogatiues of old Rome.
Con≈øtantinople is called by the Turkes Stambolda.

Con≈øtantinople was likewi≈øe called Ethu≈øe and Antonie, but by the Grecians Stimboli, and of the Turks Stambolda, which in their language ≈øignifieth a large City, and ≈øo it is called by them at this day.

The Emperour now ≈øeeing his Citie builded and ≈øufficiently peopled, compa≈ø≈øed the ≈øame with walles, towers and ditches, building therein many ≈øumptuous Temples, adorning it with many magnifique buildings, and nece≈ø≈øary works as well publik as priuate.

And afterwards for the more beautifying thereof, cau≈øed to be brought from Rome diuers Antiquities worthy of memorie, and among≈øt others the Palladium of ancient Troy, that is, the image of P ‚Ä¢ llas in Troy, which he cau≈øed to be ≈øet in the place of Placote the great columne of Porphyre which was ≈øet vp in the ≈øame place. Neere vnto which he cau≈øed to be erected a Statue of bra≈ø≈øe, to the likene≈ø≈øe of Apollo, of a maruailous bigne≈ø≈øe, in which place hee ordained his name to ve ≈øet vp. But in the time of the Emperour Al ‚Ä¢ xis Comine this Statue, through a great and impetuous tempe≈øt, was ca≈øt down to the ground, and broken all to pieces.

This Emperour liued there many y√©eres mo≈øt pro≈øperou≈øly
in happy e≈øtate, as likewi≈øe did many of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, but not altogether exempted from per≈øecutions, as well by wars, fires, pe≈øtilence, earth-quakes, as ≈øundry other calamities, vntill ≈øuch time as God purpo≈øing to puni≈øh the people for their ≈øins, through negligence of Emperours, ≈øtirred vp Mahomet the ≈øecond of that name, and the eighth Emperour vnto the Turkes, who being mooued with an earne≈øt de≈øire to bring the Chri≈øtians vnto decay, and thereby to augment his Empire, being beyond mea≈øure iealous to ≈ø√©e this noble City ≈øo flori≈øh before his eies, went with a maruellous power both by ≈øea and by land, to giue a furious ≈øiege vnto the City: The end and i≈ø≈øue whereof was ≈øuch, that after a long ≈øiege, battery, and diuers a≈ø≈øaults, the Jnfidels hauing gotten the wals, with a great hurlyburly and fury entred into the city: where at the fir≈øt entry they made The death of Con≈øtantine the Emperor. a maruellou ≈ølaughter of the poore a≈ø≈øieged Chri≈øtians, without ≈øparing any age or degr√©e. The Emperour Con≈øtantine they killed in the prea≈øe, as he though to haue ≈øaued him≈øelfe; and after that they had cut off his head, in deri≈øion and ignominy, they carried the ≈øame vpon the point of a ≈øpeare, round about the Campe and City. And afterwards Mahomet not contenting him≈øelfe with the violating and deflouring of the Emperours wife, daughters, and other Ladies of honour, by a ≈øauage cruelty, cau≈øed them in his pre≈øence to be di≈ømembred and cut in p√©eces. During the time of the ≈øacking (which continued thr√©e daies) there was no kinde of fornication, Sodometry, ≈øacrilege, nor cruelty, by them left vnexecuted.

They ≈øpoiled the incomparable Temple of S. Sophia (which was built by the Emperour Iu≈øtinian) of all ornaments and hallowed ve≈ø≈øels,The Temple of S. Sophia was made a ≈øtewes. and made thereof a ≈øtable, and a brodell for buggerers and whores.

This lamentable lo≈ø≈øe of Con≈øtantinople, being chiefe of the Orientall Empire, and likewi≈øe of the City of Perah, by the Turkes called Gallata, being the ≈øeat of trade of the Geneuoi≈øes, lying hard by Con≈øtantinople, vpon the other ≈øide of the Chanell, was in the y√©ere of our Sauiour 1453. March 29. (≈øome doe ≈øay of Aprill, and others of May) after it had remained vnder the dominion of the Chri≈øtians 1198. y√©eres.

But this is a maruellous thing, and worthy to be noted, that Con≈øtantinople being reedified and new ≈øet vp by Con≈øtantine the ≈øonne of S. Helene (whom ≈øome report to haue beene an Engli≈øhwoman borne at Cholche≈øter) after the proportion and likene≈ø≈øe of Rome, was by another Con≈øtantine, ≈øonne of another Helene, taken, ≈øacked, and brought into the hands of the Turkes, which foreuer is like to be (in the iudgement of man) an irreparable dammage vnto al Chri≈øtendome. Yet the Turks haue a Prophecie, that as the Empire was gotten by Mahomet, ≈øo by another of that name Mahomet it ≈øhall be lo≈øt againe.

Mahomet, after h√©e had thus taken the City,The policie of Mahomet. re≈øoluing to k√©epe there the ≈øeat of his Empire, cau≈øed (with all diligence) the wals to be new made, and certaine other ruinated places to be repaired. And in ≈øtead of the great number of the people that were there ≈ølaine and carried away as pri≈øoners, he cau≈øed to be brought thither, out of all the Prouinces and Cities by him conquered, a certaine number of men, women, and children, with their faculties and riches, whom he permitted there to liue according to the in≈øtitutions and precepts of ≈øuch Religion as it plea≈øed them to ob≈øerue, and to exerci≈øe with all ≈øafety, their handicrafts and merchandi≈øes; which mini≈øtred an occa≈øion vnto an infinite multitude of Iewes and Marannes, driuen out of Spaine, for to come and dwell there: By meanes whereof, in very ≈øhort time the City began to increa≈øe in trafficke, riches, and abundance of people.

This Mahomet was the fir≈øt founder of the great Seralia (where the great Turke now v≈øually dwelleth) which he builded at the entry of the channell, about one of the corners of the City, vpon the Promontorie Chri≈øo≈øeras, which afterwards by the great Turkes which ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely haue dwelled there, hath b√©ene greatly beautified and augmented.

He sounded likewi≈øe vpon one of the Mounts of the ≈øame City, a ≈øumptuous Muskia or Church, with an Amarathe and College, enduing them all with great y√©erely reuennues: which is not to be maruelled at, for fortune was ≈øo fauourable vnto him, that after he had ruinated the Empire of Con≈øtantinople and Trapezonde, he tooke from the Chri≈øtians 12. Kingdomes,
and 200. Cities; ≈øo that, by rea≈øon of his great prowe≈ø≈øes and Conque≈øts, the name and title of [Great] was giuen vnto him, and to this day remaineth vnto the hou≈øe of the Ottomans: As the Turke who died about foure y√©eres ≈øince, was called Sultan Mahomet, the Grand Chan of Turkey, and the fourt√©enth of the Line of Ottoman. And his ≈øonne which now raigneth (being not yet aboue twenty y√©eres of age) is called Sultan Achomet the fifteenth Grand Chan of the Line of Ottoman: and writeth him≈øelfe al≈øo (as his Predece≈ø≈øors haue done) King of the blacke and white Seas, and of the holy Cities Mecha and Ieru≈øalem:
Proijcit ampullas & ≈øe≈øquipedalia verba:
Lofty words he ca≈øteth out,
And arrogant titles ≈øends about.

Ouer again≈øt Con≈øtantinople about the Seralia point,Perah or Gallata. on the other ≈øide the water, there is another City called Gallata or Perah, which (in ancient time) was called Cornubizantij. It is a City of great antiquity, builded by the Genoezes. It is called by the Greekes vulgarly Perah, which is a Gr√©eke word, ≈øignifying beyond, becau≈øe it is ≈øituated beyond the Canall. But by the Turkes it is called Gallata.

div.head: Of fearfull fires and terrible Earth-quakes, which haue happened within Con≈øtantinople.
div.p:
ZOnoras the Con≈øtantinopolitan Hi≈øtorian maketh mention in his Hi≈øtories, of two fearfull fires which happened vnto Con≈øtantinople, whereof the fir≈øt was in the time and Empire of Leon the great, ≈øpreading it ≈øelfe from the North vnto the South, along by Bo≈øphorus, to wit, the length of one of the Seas to the other, and was ≈øo horrible and furious for the ≈øpace of foure daies, that it deuoured and brought to a≈øhes the whole beauty of the City, namely, the place where the Senate and Citizens (cho≈øen to deliberate vpon common affaires) did a≈ø≈øemble. There was al≈øo burned another princely hou≈øe, and a
Pallace ioyning vnto the caue or den called Nymphee, and diuers other Churches and priuate hou≈øes.

The ≈øecond fire which was in the time and raigne of the Emperour Ba≈øil, lightned in ≈øuch ≈øort, that it compa≈ø≈øed the market of Copper, and con≈øumed to a≈øhes the hou≈øes and ≈øtr√©ets thereabouts with y‚Ä¢ Pallace, within which was a Librarie of 120000. volumes of Bookes, and the Stature of a Dragon of the length of 120. foot, which was written in letters of gold; the Jlliads, and the Odi≈ø≈øe of Homer. And moreouer, burned the mo≈øt renowned ≈øimulachres of Juno, of Samos, of Minerua, of Lynde, of Venus, and of Guide; and finally deuoured the mo≈øt plea≈øant places of the Citie.

H√©ereunto may I adde a third fire which befell the ≈øame Citie Anno Dom. 1607. October 14. wherein were burned 3000. hou≈øes together vnder Sultan Achomet, the 15. Grand-Chan of the line of Ottoman, who now raigneth.

div.head: Of two fearefull Earth-quakes which happened to CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.p: THE ≈øaid Zonoras reciteth, that during the raigne of Ana≈øta≈øius cho≈øen vnto the Empire of the Ea≈øt parts, there happened ≈øuch a great earthquake, that it ruined euen to the foundations, a great number of buildings, not onely at Con≈øtantinople, but likewi≈øe in Bythinia, and other places thereabout.

But the la≈øt (whereof diuers worthy Authors haue written, namely Mun≈øter in his Geographie) was ≈øo ≈øtrange & fearefull for the ≈øpace of 18. dayes continually, that with horrible fearefulne≈ø≈øe & dammage, it ca≈øt downe to the ground the walles of the Citie, and all the buildings towards the ≈øea ≈øide, and ouerthrew all the ditches. It did al≈øo ca≈øt downe the Tower where the Turk kept his munition, with fiue others more. The hou≈øe of Tribute which ≈øtoode n√©ere vnto the walle, was ouerthrowen euen to the foundation into the ≈øea, with the Leadings of the waters and conduits, which, with incredible expences had beene made to leade the waters out of the Danube into the
Citie, were for the mo≈øt part broken and brui≈øed. And the chanell which is betwixt Con≈øtantinople and Perah was ≈øo moued, that by great ≈øurges it ca≈øt the water ouer the walles of both the Cities.

But the wor≈øt of all was, that more then 13000. per≈øons remained dead on an heape. This great Earthquake happened in the moneth of September, in the yeere of grace 1509. in the raigne of Baiazeth the ≈øecond of that name, and the 9. Emperour vnto the Turkes (which ≈øucc√©eded Mahomet the ≈øecond) who, with all diligence cau≈øed the walles of the Citie to be repaired.

The re≈øt of the noble Antiquities which pre≈øently are to be found at Con≈øtantinople, are the Hippodrome, which the Turkes doe call Atmaiden, which is the place where in times pa≈øt the Emperours made the hor≈øes to run for the plea≈øure and delectation of the people, which beheld the ≈øame vpon a ≈øtage or theater, which now is altogether ruined. In the midde≈øt of this place, was ≈øet vp vpon foure bowles of fine marble, a faire Obeli≈øquie of coloured ≈øtone, all of one piece, 50. cubits high, be≈øet with letters Hieroglificke; and n√©ere to it is a great columne, in the which are carued by hi≈øtories the things memorable, which haue b√©ene done in this Hippodrome.

There is al≈øo another great columne n√©ere vnto it of marble, and one of bra≈ø≈øe, made by ≈øingular arte, in forme of thr√©e ≈øerpents, wroonge one within another. And diuers other Antiquities which are di≈øper≈øed in diuers places of the Cities; as, the Palace of Con≈øtantine the great, her fir≈øt re≈øtorer, which ioyneth vnto the walles n√©ere vnto the corner which is towards the We≈øt.The Sepulcher of Con≈øtantine, of Porphyre. The Sepulcher of the ≈øame Con≈øtantine, which is madeall of Porphyre, being in a corner of a ≈øtreete, the mo≈øt filthie≈øt in all the Citie.
And going towards the gate of Seliuree, is to be ≈ø√©ene a great Columne of marble, hi≈øtoried after the manner of tho≈øe of Antonie and Adrian which are at Rome.
Moreouer, there are Conduit pipes, and diuers Ce≈øternes vaulted, ≈øupported, ≈øome by vaults, and other ≈øome by a great number of pillers, and diuers other fragments of Antiquities.

There are al≈øo two places in Con≈øtantinople at this day,Beze≈øtan. like vnto the Exchange in London, called the Beze≈øtan, di≈øtingui≈øhed by the≈øe names, The old Beze≈øtan, and, The new Beze≈øtan, wherein all ≈øorts of commodities are to be bought, as in the Royall Exchange in London, and greater variety, as veluets, ≈øilkes, and ≈øattins, and wa≈øte-coats ready made of all ≈øorts of ≈øilke, finely quilted and curiou≈øly wrought, with curious handkerchiefes of exqui≈øite worke, and many other commodities, which were too long to ≈øet downe. But the≈øe Beze≈øtans are not open all the day, but at certaine houres, vz. from nine of the clocke in the morning, to three or foure in the afternoone; and not euery day neither, but on certaine daies in the w√©eke.

There is al≈øo a v≈øual market in Con≈øtantinople, Markets of men. wherein they ≈øell men and women of all ages as ordinarily as we doe cattle in England, which are (for the mo≈øt part) Chri≈øtians, ≈øuch as the Turkes take captiues in Hungarie or other places where they ouercome: Their cu≈øtome is to make ≈ølaues of all they can take aliue, and (at their returne) to ≈øell them in the open market. If Chri≈øtians be moued in compa≈ø≈øion to buy them, becau≈øe they are Chri≈øtians, the Turkes will ≈øell them exc√©eding deare to them, but cheape to a Mu≈ø≈ølelman (as they call them≈øelues) that is, true beleeuers. But if they cannot get their owne price for them, they will enforce them to turne Turks, and to ≈øerue them in all ≈øeruile labours as the I≈øraelites did the Egyptians.

∆≤pon the corner of the Citie,Of the seuen Towers. which ≈øtretcheth towards Gall ‚Ä¢ poly, neere vnto the ≈øea ≈øide, there is a very ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle compa≈ø≈øed with 7. great towers, & enuironed with high and ≈øtrong walles, well furni≈øhed with artillery; which Ca≈øtle is by the Turkes called Iadicule, but commonly, The ≈øeuen Towers. For the k√©eping whereof, there is a Captaine called Di≈ødaragla, a man of great reuenewes and Authoritie, which ordinarily hath vnder him 500. dead payes, called A≈ø≈øarelies, which haue all b√©en Iene≈øaries, and haue euery one of them for their wages 5000. A≈øpers by the yeere. And there the great Turke keepeth ≈øuch Guard, for that he and other Emperours Turkes, his predece≈ø≈øours, haue alwayes there kept the Trea≈øures, & yet the Grand-Sig ‚Ä¢ ior commeth thither very ≈øeldome. This Ca≈øtle al≈øo with
≈øeuen Towers (commonly called The ≈øeuen Towers) is a Pri≈øon for great men, like vnto the Tower of London.

There are al≈øo two other ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles which I haue ≈ø√©ene towards the Blacke Sea (called Mare Euxinum) wherinto they put pri≈øoners of whom they make great account, and for whom they expect great ran≈øome.

At the Blacke ≈øea we ≈øaw Pompeis Piller of marble, erected one a rocky Iland, neere vnto the ≈øhoare, whereon ≈øome of our company wrote their names, viz. ma≈øter Robert Yong, Gentleman (who also there wrote the name of our noble Prince HENRY)

Our ≈øhip being not ready to ≈øet ≈øaile at our returne from the mount, but ≈øtaying partly to di≈øpatch their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and partly

We ≈øaw al≈øo Baruta, where ≈øomtimes was a great trade for Merchants, but from thence they remooued it to Dama≈øcus, and from Dama≈øcus to Tripoly, and of late, from Tripoly to Sidon. Ioppa is not farre from the≈øe parts, oftentimes Barkes come from the one to the other.

At our returne wee went aboard,Scanderon. and pre≈øently ≈øet ≈øaile for Scanderone, (as it is now called by Turks:) otherwi≈øe called Alexandretta by the Chri≈øtians, which is the very bottome and vtmo≈øt border of all the ≈øtraights. The ayre is very corrupt, and infecteth the bodies, and corrupteth the blood of ≈øuch as continue there many daies, partly by rea≈øon of the dregs of the ≈øea, which are driuen thither: and partly by rea≈øon of two high mountaines which keepe a way the ≈øunne from it a great part of the day. And it is very dangerous for ≈øtrangers to come on ≈øhoare before the ≈øunne be two houres high, and haue dried vp the vapors of the ground, or to ≈øtay on ≈øhoare after ≈øunne ≈øetting. The waters al≈øo n√©ere vnto the towne are very vnhol≈øome, comming from a moori≈øh ground; but at the fountaine, a mile off, there is exc√©eding good water to drinke. Scanderone is in Cilicia, and Cilicia is the countrie Caramonia, (as it is now called) in the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, and is diuided into two parts, viz. Trocher and Campe≈øtris. It hath on the Ea≈øt, the hill Amanus: on the North, Taurus: on the We≈øt, Pamphila: on the South, the Cilician ≈øea.

Scanderone is the port for Aleppo, where all our Merchants
land their goods, and ≈øend them vp to Aleppo, vpon Cammels. The Carauans v≈øually make thr√©e daies iourney betwixt Scanderone and Aleppo. Whiles our Cammels were preparing, we tooke boat and went to an ancient towne by the ≈øea ≈øide, called at this day Byas, Tar≈øius in Cilicia. but of old, Tar≈øus, a Citie in Cilicia where S. At the gardens neere Tar≈øus (and likewi≈øe at other gardens within three miles of Scanderone) we ≈øaw great ≈øtore of Silkewormes, which at the fir≈øt bee but little graines like vnto Mu≈øtard≈øeed: but by the bearing of them in womens bo≈øomes, they doe gather an heat, whereby they come vnto life, and ≈øo proue wormes; they k√©epe them in tents made of r√©eds with one loft ouer another full of them, and f√©ed them with leaues of Mulbery tr√©es; the≈øe wormes (by naturall in≈øtinct) doe fa≈øt often, (as ≈øome report) euery third day.

Heere we ≈øtaied certaine dayes to auoid the infection of Scanderone. The mountaines which ob≈øcure Scanderone, and make it more vnhealthfull, I take to be a part of Taurus, which is a great and famous Mountaine, beginning at the Indian Sea, and ri≈øing into the North, pa≈ø≈øeth by A≈øia vnto Moeotis, bordering vpon many Countries, and is called by many names. Sometimes it is called Amanus, which hill parteth Syria from Cilicia. And ≈øometimes it is called by other names, according vnto the ≈øea coa≈øts along which it extendeth.

About Scanderone there are many rauenous bea≈øts about the bigne≈ø≈øe of a For, commonly called there Iackalles, engendered (as they ≈øay) of a Fox and a Woolfe, which in the night make a great crying, and come to the graues, and if there haue b√©ene any cor≈øe buried the day before, (if the graue be not well filled, with many great ≈øtones vpon it) many of them together, with their feet, doe ≈øcrape vp the earth, and pull vp the corps and eat it.

At our returne from Thar≈øus, Edward Ro≈øe our Factor marine

Our Merchants and pa≈ø≈øengers making ha≈øte to bee gone from this contagious and pe≈øtiferous place Scanderone (which one very well called,Malims are chiefe Carriers. The bane of Franks) left their goods with the Factor Marine to be ≈øent after them, becau≈øe the Malims and Muckremen (as they call the Carriers) were not yet come down with their Cammels to carry them vp:Muckremen ≈øet hor≈øes to hire. but we met them at the fountaine of fi≈øhes n√©ere vnto Scanderone.

About eight miles from Scanderone, we came to a towne called Bylan, Bylan. where there lieth buried an Engli≈øh Gentleman, named Henry Mori≈øon, who died there comming downe from Aleppo in companie with his brother ma≈øter Phines Mori≈øon, who left his Armes in that countrie with the≈øe ver≈øes vnder written.

div.p: From Bylan we came to the plaine of Antioch, and went ouer the Riuer Orontes by boate,Orontes. which Riuer parteth Antiochia and Syria. Antioch plaine is very long & large, at lea≈øt 10. miles in length.Antiochia in Pi≈øidia. Wee lodged the fir≈øt night at Antiochia in Pi≈øidia, an ancient towne about 25. miles from Scanderone, mentioned Act. 11. 26. where the Di≈øciples were fir≈øt called Chri≈øtians. H√©ere we lodged in an hou≈øe, but on the bare ground, hauing nothing to ≈øl√©epe on, or to couer vs, but what we brought with vs, viz. a pillow, a ‚Ä¢ d a quilt at the mo≈øt, and that was lodging for a Lord.

This Antioch hath beene, as a famous, ≈øo an exc√©eding ≈øtrong Towne, ≈øituated by the Sea, and almo≈øt compa≈ø≈øed (at the lea≈øt on both ≈øides) with exc√©eding high and ≈øtrong rockes. The Inhabitants at this day are Gr√©ekes, but vnder the gouernement
of the Turke, but for matters of Religion, ordered and ruled by their Patriarchs, for the Gr√©eks haue foure Patriarchs to this pre≈øent day, viz. The Patriarch of Antioch, the Patriarch of Ieru≈øalem, the Patriarch of Alexandria, the Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople, who ruleth all the re≈øt. Yet as the Iewes, ≈øo al≈øo the Greekes to this day are without a king, and both they, and their Patriarks are but ≈ølaues to the great Turke.

And although their Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople bee counted their chiefe Patriarch: yet I haue knowen one Mile≈øius (a learned man ind√©ed) who was fir≈øt Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople, preferred to the place by ma≈øter Edward Barton, an Engli≈øh Gentleman, and Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour for Qu√©ene Elizabeth, of famous memorie, (and the mirror of all Amba≈ø≈øadours that euer came to Con≈øtantinople) who for his wi≈øedome, good gouernment, policie, and Chri≈øtian cariage hath left an immortal fame behind him in tho≈øe Countries, to this pre≈øent day, and lieth buried at an Iland of the Gr√©eks,Bartons Iland. within twelue miles of Con≈øtantinople called Bartons Iland to this day.

After who≈øe death, this good man Mile≈øius was by the Gr√©eks di≈øplaced from being Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople: (which they dur≈øt not doe whiles ma≈øter Barton was liuing) becau≈øe, being a man of knowledge, he laboured to reforme the Greekes from many of their ≈øuper≈øtitious cu≈øtomes. Whereupon (pre≈øently after the death of ma≈øter Barton) they ≈øaid their Patriarch was an Engli≈øhman, and no Gr√©eke, and therefore Manzulled him, that is: di≈øplaced him. Yet bearing ≈øome reuerence towards him for his learning, made him Patriarch of Alexandria. And being there Patriarch, he excommunicated the Patriarch of Antiochia, becau≈øe he accepted of reliefe at the Popes hand; and made him come to Alexandria, to humble him≈øelfe vnto him, and acknowledge his fault before he would ≈øuffer him to execute his Patriarkes office.

Ma≈øter Henry Lello (a learned, wi≈øe, and religious Engli≈øh gentleman, ≈øometime ≈øtudent in Oxford, and afterwards at the Innes of the Court) ≈øucc√©eded Ma≈øter Barton in his place, and in many things exc√©eded him, e≈øpecially in his religious carriage and vn≈øpotted life: and had not the times b√©ene more
trouble≈øome in his regiment, than in the time of his predece≈ø≈øor Ma≈øter Barton; he would euery way haue gone beyond him. He fir≈øt of all reformed his family, and afterwards ≈øo ordered him≈øelfe in his whole carriage, that he credited our Countrey: and after ten y√©eres gouernment of the Engli≈øh Nation there, he returned into his Countrey with the teares of many, & with generall good report of al Nations there dwelling or ≈øoiourning; & is worthily by his excellent Maie≈øty rewarded with Knighthood for his good ≈øeruice.
If Mile≈øius had liued, this good gentleman would haue re≈øtored him to Con≈øtantinople, as he placed many other Archbi≈øhops both at Salonica, (of old called The≈ø≈øalonica) and el≈øewhere.

In the Mountaines betwixt Scanderone and Aleppo, Coords. there are dwelling a certaine kind of people called at this day Coords, comming of the race of the ancient Parthians, who wor≈øhip the Deuill, and allege for their rea≈øon in ≈øo doing, that God is a good man, and will doe no man harme, but that the Deuill is bad, and mu≈øt be plea≈øed le≈øt he hurt them. There is al≈øo,Archills ‚Ä¢ s. although not in the direct way, (yet for ≈øafety and plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of the way, it is ≈øometimes taken in the way to Aleppo) an ancient City called Achilles, where one A≈øan Ba≈øhaw ruleth like a King (paying duties to the Turkes) ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely from his predece≈ø≈øors, comming of the hou≈øe of Sanballat, who hindred the building of the Temple of Ieru≈øalem, who is called to this day,Nehe. 4. 1. Eben Sumbolac, that is, the ≈øonne of Sanballat: and all his kinred call one another, Ammiogli, that is, Brother Ammonite; for they account them≈øelues of the race of the Ammonites. This A≈øan Ba≈øhaw is now old, and (for the mo≈øt part) referreth all matters of gouernment to his kin≈øman V≈øeph Bege, that is, Lord Io≈øeph.

The ≈øecond night, in our trauell from Scanderone, we lodged at a place called The gardens, in the open fields, hauing the ground to our bed, a ≈øtone to our pillow (as Iacob in his trauell had) and the ≈økie to our couering. And many poore trauellers in
the≈øe parts (who come vnprouided) haue nothing els but the air for their ≈øupper, except they can meet with the fruits of tr√©es, or hearbes of the fields. We met in ≈øome places with villages of Tents, where our Iene≈øarie Parauan Ba≈øhaw (being partly feared and partly loued among≈øt them) brought vnto vs from them, bread and water often times. At one place we had al≈øo pre≈øented to vs very good ≈øweet goats milke, and al≈øo good ≈øowre milke, turned by art, which is the mo≈øt common di≈øh in tho≈øe hot Countries.

The day following,Hauadan. we came about noone to a village called Hanadan, eight miles on this ≈øide Aleppo, ouer again≈øt which village, on the right hand, on the top of the hill, there is (as the Jewes report) the ≈øepulcher of the Prophet Ieremie. At this village we dined with Mu≈ømelons,Sambou≈øes are little pa≈øties. Sambou≈øes, and a Muclebite. Syria is in A≈øia, A de≈øcription of Syria. hauing on the Ea≈øt, Euphrates: on the We≈øt, Aegypt; on the North, Cilicia; on the South, Arabia.

A≈ø≈øyria ioineth vnto Syria, and hath on the Ea≈øt, Media; on the We≈øt, Me≈øopotamia; on the North, Armenia Minor; on the South, Su≈øiana. About ≈øixty miles from Aleppo, the riuer Euphrates and Tygris m√©et, at a place called vulgarly Beere or Birha, but of old it was called Me≈øopotamia, Me≈øopotamia where Laban dwelt at Padan Aram. And there is yet a heape of ≈øtones (within halfe a daies iourny of Aleppo, n√©ere vnto Taedith, inhabited by Iewes) where Laban following after Iacob, made couenant with him, which Laban called Iegar-≈øahadutha, that is, An heape of Witne≈ø≈øes.
