The City Niniue was in A≈ø≈øyria, Nineue. ≈øituated by Tygris, whereof

But in the place where Niniueh ≈øtood, there is a little towne called Mu≈øcla, from whence the inhabitants of that place bring a kinde of linnen cloath called Mu≈ølina, to Aleppo, to ≈øell to Merchants there. At B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ha, by the Riuer Euphrates, they that goe Babylon, v≈øually take boat, but ≈øtay vntill their boats be made, and then buy them, and goe downe the Riuer Euphrates with a ≈øwift currant, but cannot come backe againe by water.

Babylon is now called by the Turkes, Babylon is called Badg ‚Ä¢ t Bagdat. It is al≈øo gouerned by Turkes. It bordereth vpon Per≈øia. Betwixt Aleppo and Babylon, Merchants trauell often ouer the de≈øart of Arabia, and euery quarter of the y√©ere Carauans come from thence with many hundred Camels laden with merchandi≈øe. And their cu≈øtome hath b√©ene,Pigions carrying letters. and is ≈øtill ≈øometimes, when they haue occa≈øion to ≈øend ≈øome ≈øudden newes from Babylon to fa≈øten ≈øome briefe writing to one of the wings of a Bagdat or Babylonian pigeon, or about her necke, in ≈øuch ≈øort that it may not hinder her flying, and to ≈øend her therewith to bring newes to Aleppo, which is at the lea≈øt ten daies iourney off: which when I heard at the fir≈øt, it ≈ø√©emed to me wonderfull ≈øtrange, and almo≈øt incredible: but after I vnder≈øtood how they traine them to it, the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe thereof was dimini≈øhed. For when the hen doue ≈øitteth, or hath yoong ones, they take the cocke pigeon and put him in a cage, and when the Carriers goe with their camels, they ≈øet the pigeon in an open cage on a camels backe, and when they are a daies iourney or two from home, ≈øet her at liberty, who pre≈øently mounteth vp aloft, and beholding her way, neuer cea≈øeth flying vntill ≈øhe come to her mate; which any of the hou≈øe perceiuing, looke for ≈øome paper fa≈øtned about her, and ≈øo in po≈øt ha≈øte vnder≈øtand ≈øpeedie newes. And ≈øo by degrees they traine them further & further to the places of their trafficke. This I haue knowen put in practi≈øe, and performed by an Engli≈øh Merchant of Aleppo, who in ≈øuch ≈øort ≈øent a Bagdat pigeon to Scanderone, three daies
iourney from Aleppo, and by her returne, vnder≈øtood when ≈øhips arriued thither, and departed from thence: which ≈ø√©emeth not vnto me ≈øo ≈øtrange as that which we reade of, performed by a Cobler of Rome, who taught a dawe to ≈øpeake, and to ≈øalute the Emperour, as he pa≈ø≈øed by, with the≈øe words, Salue Cae≈øar; which the Emperour hearing, gaue vnto the Cobler a good reward, and bought his dawe: which another poore man in Rome perceiuing, hoping to get the like reward, tooke vpon him to teach another daw, the ≈øame le≈ø≈øon; and day and night as he ≈øate at his work v≈øed ≈øtill to prattle vnto his daw, and bid him ≈øay, Salue Cae≈øar: and when he perceiued he could not make his daw once frame him≈øelf to pronounce tho≈øe words, he chafing, rapped him on the bill, and ≈øaid, Operam & oleum perdidi; that is, I haue lo≈øt my labour in vaine: yet ≈øtill continued his diligent endeuour, and by often repeating both Salue Cae≈øar, and Operam & oleum perdidi, in the end his daw had learned both the one and the other, and when the Emperour pa≈ø≈øed by, ≈øaid, Salue Cae≈øar; the Emperour an≈øwered, Tales habeo domi ≈øalutatores; that is, J haue ≈øuch ≈øaluters inow at home: whereupon the daw replied, Operam & oleum perdidi: which the Emperour hearing, bought this daw al≈øo, becau≈øe he had one le≈ø≈øon more than the other, and rewarded the poore man well for his labour.

I am bold to write vnto you in ab≈øence as plea≈øantly as I was wont to ≈øpeake vnto you in pre≈øence, whereby you may perceiue I am ≈øtill the ≈øame man, and of the ≈øame minde, and as merry out of England as euer I was in England.

But to proc√©ed in my di≈øcour≈øe and de≈øcription of Syria: A de≈øcription of Syria. All Syria of old was called Aram, and the Syrians, Aramites. But e≈øpecially I doe read of thr√©e of the chiefe≈øt Cities in Syria called by the name Aram: The fir≈øt was Aram Naharaim, which was Me≈øopotamia; for Nahar in Hebrue ≈øignifieth a Riuer, and Naharaim is the duall number thereof, ≈øignifying two Riuers, which were Euphrates and Tygris. Me≈øopotamia the Gr√©eke word ≈øignifieth the ≈øame, comming of two Gr√©eke words, viz.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifieth the middle, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifieth a Riuer: and therefore was it called Me≈øopotamia, becau≈øe it
was ≈øituated betw√©ene two Riuers, that is, Euphrates and Tygris.
The ≈øecond was Aram Dama≈øek, that is, Dama≈øcus, which is ≈øtill the chiefe≈øt City in all Syria.

The third was called Aram Sobah, which ≈øome thinke to haue b√©ene that City which is now called Aleppo. And of this Aram Sobah I finde mention made, 2. Sam 8. 3. 4. 5. And al≈øo in the title of the ≈øixty P≈øalme, where mention is made of the ≈øalt valley which is but halfe a daies iourney from Aleppo, which is a very great plaine, without gra≈ø≈øe growing on it, the very ≈øand whereof is good ≈øalt naturally: after raine, being dried againe by the ≈øunne, they gather it. There is al≈øo a little Iland or mountaine in the mid≈øt thereof, plaine on the toppe, which y√©eldeth the be≈øt ≈øalt.

Some Iewes there dwelling, doe al≈øo ≈øay, that Aleppo was the City Sepheruaim: but I thinke it to be a latter City, which ≈øome ≈øay was called Apollonius: but I know no rea≈øon for it, except it were built by one of that name. How≈øoeuer, it ≈øhould ≈ø√©eme this City Aleppo hath often changed her name, and that, if it were not Aram Sobah, yet to be built not farre from the place where Aram Sobah ≈øtood. But the Turkes (changing the names of all places where they come) call Aleppo at this day, Halep, which ≈øignifieth Milke, becau≈øe it y√©eldeth great ≈øtore of milke.
Aleppo is inhabited by Turkes, Moores, Arabians, Iewes, Greekes, Armenians, Chelfalines, No≈øtranes, and people of ≈øundry other Nations.

The Turkes come of Magog the ≈øonne „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Iapheth. For (as we reade, Gen. 10. 1.) Noah had thr√©e ≈øonnes, Shem, Ham, and Iapheth.

Shem and his po≈øterity dwelt in Syria, in Chaldaea, and in Per≈øia, being the Ea≈øt parts of the world, whence came the Syrians, the Aramites, the Chaldeans, and the Per≈øians. The ≈øons of Shem are named, Gen. 10. 22. to be the≈øe, Elam, A≈øhur, Lud, and Aram. Of Elam came the Elamites or Per≈øians; of A≈øhur, the A≈ø≈øyrians; of Lud, the Lydians; of Aram, the Aramites or Syrians. The≈øe ≈øonnes of Shem, with their po≈øteritie, are ca≈øt
out of the holy Line, who were deadly enemies to their kindred, Gen. 10. 22. 23.

Ham with his ≈ø√©ed went into Canaan, being the South part of the world, of whom came the Cananites, the Egyptians, Ethiopians, and the Arabians. The ≈øonnes of Ham are ≈øet downe, Gen. 10. 6. 7. 8. 9. 10. &c. to be the≈øe, Cu≈øh, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
Of Cu≈øh came Nimrod a mighty hunter, the builder of Babel.
Of Mizraim came the Egyptians, who in Hebrew are called Mizraims.
Of Put came the Blacke-Moores.
Of Canaan the Cananites: And ≈øo foorth, as you may reade, Gen. 10.
Iapheth went with his ≈ø√©ed into the We≈øterne and Northern parts of the world: Of whom came the Greekes, the Medes, the Simbrians, the Germanes, the Scythians, the Turkes, and the Thratitians.
The Iles of the Gentiles came of Iapheth and his ≈øonnes.
The ≈øonnes of Iapheth are ≈øet downe, Gen. 10. 2. 5. to b√©e the≈øe, Gomer, Magog, Madai, Iauan, Tuball, Me≈øech, Tiras, &c.
Of Gomer came the Tartarians.
Of Magog the Turkes and Scythians.
Of Madai, the Medes.
Of Iauan, the people of A≈øia and Graecia.

And what people proc√©eded of the re≈øt, you may reade Ezech. 27. 1. 13. Ezech. 38. 1. 2. &c. Ezech. 39. 2. vnto which places I referre you for the re≈øt: for I de≈øire to be briefe, le≈øt by ouer prolixne≈ø≈øe in writing, I be ouer tedious to you in reading.

I promi≈øed you in my la≈øt letters,Religion of the Turkes. to write vnto you by the next, of the Religion, Gouernment, Manners, and Cu≈øtomes of the Turkes, and other Nations there dwelling or ≈øoiourning. Wherfore, that I may the better make knowen vnto you their Religion, I will begin with the fir≈øt Author thereof, which was (no doubt) the Deuill, who v≈øed that fal≈øe Prophet Mahomet as his in≈øtrument to broach it abroad.

Diuers Prophets haue foretold of the wickedne≈ø≈øe and tyrannie of the Turkes: but I will only recite the Prophecie of
Daniell, chap. 7. 7. which is very notable, and agr√©eth e≈øpecially vnto the time when this impiety and tyranny did beginne. After this (≈øaith Daniel) I ≈øaw in the vi≈øions by night, and behold, the fourth bea≈øt was fearefull, and terrible, and very ≈øtrong. It had great iron teeth; It deuoured, and brake in peeces, and ≈øtamped the re≈øidue vnder his feet; and it was vnlike to the bea≈øts that were before it, for it had ten hornes. Hitherto ≈øpake Daniel of the fourth, that is, the Romane Empire, and of the crueltie of the ≈øame, and of the ten Kings in ≈øubiection thereunto.

Now followeth the Prophecie of the Turki≈øh Kingdome, in the≈øe words, Dan. 7. 8. As I con≈øidered the hornes, behold, there came vp among them another little horne, before whom there were three of the fir≈øt hornes pluckt away. And behold, in this horne were eies like the eies of a man, and a mouth ≈øpeaking pre≈øumptuous things.

And afterwards, ver≈øe 23. The fourth bea≈øt ≈øhall be the fourth Kingdome in the earth, which ≈øhall bee vnlike to all the Kingdomes, and ≈øhall deuoure the whole earth, and ≈øhall tread it downe, and breake it in peeces. And the ten hornes out of this Kingdome, are ten Kings that ≈øhall ri≈øe; and another ≈øhall ri≈øe after them, and he ≈øhall be vnlike to the fir≈øt, and he ≈øhall ≈øubdue three Kings, and ≈øhall ≈øpeake words again≈øt the mo≈øt high, and thinke that he may change times and lawes. Hitherto Daniell, who≈øe Prophecie the euent hath prooued to be true.Mahomets birth and parentage. For Anno Dom. 591. (Mauritius then Emperor of the Romanes & raining in Con≈øtantinople) was Mahomet borne in Arabia, in a ba≈øe village called Itraripia. His parents were of diuers Nations, and different in Religion. His father Abdallas was an Arabian: His mother Cadige a Iew both by birth and profe≈ø≈øion. His parentage (according to mo≈øt Hi≈øtories) was ≈øo meane and ba≈øe, that both his birth and infancie remained ob≈øcure, and of no reckoning, till that his riper y√©eres (bewraying in him a mo≈øt ≈øubtill and crafty nature and di≈øpo≈øition) did argue ≈øome likelihood, that the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe and dexterity of his wit would in time aboli≈øh the ba≈øene≈ø≈øe and ob≈øcurity of his birth. And ≈øoone did he make ≈øhew and proofe thereof: for being trained vp of a boy in the ≈øeruice of a rich and wealthy Merchant, by his great indu≈øtry
and diligence, he ≈øo in≈øinuated and wrought him≈øelfe into the good fauour and liking both of his ma≈øter and mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe, that when his ma≈øter died, and had leaft all his wealth and riches vnto his wife, ≈øhe made choi≈øe of her ≈øeruant Mahomet for her hu≈øband, making him Lord and Ma≈øter both of her per≈øon, and of her ≈øub≈øtance. The man being thus rai≈øed from ba≈øe and low degr√©e, to great wealth and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and hauing a working and a≈øpiring head, did from thencefoorth plot and imagine how he might rai≈øe him≈øelfe in honour and reputation; pre≈øuming that the greatne≈ø≈øe of his wealth would b√©e a fit meane to worke his higher fortunes. Neither was he deceiued in the expectation of his hope: For con≈øorting him≈øelfe with one Sergius a fugitiue Monke, a notable Heretike of the Arrian Sect (whom he had made bounden vnto him by his great liberalitie) there grew ≈øo ≈øtrict a league of amity and ≈øecret familiarity betw√©ene them, that they had many times priuate conference, how and by what meanes Mahomet might make him≈øelfe way to ri≈øe in honour and e≈øtimation. After much con≈øulting and debating of the matter, the be≈øt cour≈øe which they conceiued to effect their purpo≈øe, was to coine a new kinde of Doctrine and Religion, vnder colour whereof (the times then being trouble≈øome, the people full of ≈øimplicitie and ignorance, Religion al≈øo waring cold, and neglected) they thought it an ea≈øie matter to draw many followers vnto them, and by that meanes to grow great in the eie and opinion of the world. H√©ereupon the≈øe two helhounds (one of them being an Arch enemie vnto Chri≈øt and the truth of his Religion, and the other ≈ø√©eming a m√©ere Athei≈øt or prophane per≈øon, neither perfect Iew, nor perfect Chri≈øtian) patched vp a particular doctrine vnto them≈øelues out of the old and new Te≈øtament, deprauing the ≈øen≈øe of both of them, and framing their opinions according to their owne corrupt and wicked affections; they brought foorth a mon≈øtrous and mo≈øt diuelli≈øh Religion, ≈øauouring partly of Judai≈øme, partly of Chri≈øtianity, and partly of Arriani≈øme, as I will ≈øhew you more particularly in that which followeth: But fir≈øt marke (I pray you) how Daniels Prophecie (before ≈øet downe) is prooued true.

Anno Dom. 623. Herachius being Emperour, Mahomet mooued ≈øedition, and forthwith the Saracens or Arabians ioyned together the≈øe thr√©e dominions, Egypt, Syria and Aphrica, which are the thr√©e hornes plucked from tho≈øe ten hornes of the fourth bea≈øt: and Daniel a≈øcribeth to this little horne, that is: to the Turki≈øh Empire, thr√©e notes whereby it may be knowen.
1. The fir≈øt whereof is a new Law contrary to the Law of God. For the eyes doe ≈øignifie a law ≈øubtilly inuented.
2. The ≈øecond marke is, Bla≈øphemie again≈øt the mo≈øt high, which is Chri≈øt. For the mouth ≈øpeaking words again≈øt the true God, ≈øignifieth bla≈øphemies again≈øt the Sonne of God.
3. The third note is Crueltie towards the Church; And hee ≈øhall con≈øume (≈øaith he) the Saints of the mo≈øt high.
4. The fourth is, an endeauour to Aboli≈øh the Go≈øpell and the Church. Hee ≈øhall thinke (≈øaith hee) that hee may change times and lawes.

God would haue this prophecie to be extant for a ≈øtrengthening of the godly again≈øt the crueltie of Turks, that when they ≈øhould ≈ø√©e the euent to an≈øweare to the prophecie, they might not be offended at the ≈øtumbling blocke of ≈øo great per≈øecution, and of ≈øuch reuolting from the true Church. And therefore being thus forewarned by the Prophet, let vs take heart to our ≈øelues again≈øt this Turki≈øh tyranny and wickedne≈ø≈øe, e≈øpeciallie ≈ø√©eing how the euent hath an≈øwered to the prophecie. For there haue foure Monarchies b√©ene one after an other. And now raigneth a people which are enemies to God, that openly doeth aboli≈øh the Propheticall and Apo≈øtolicall Scriptures. Thus you may ≈øee how fully Daniels prophecie is fulfilled.
I will now proc√©ed to ≈øhew more plainely how the Turkes began,How the Turks began. multiplied, and encrea≈øed.

Mahomet in his youth, by rea≈øon of his pouertie, liued by theft and robberie. Afterward hauing heaped much riches together, he was a ≈øouldier among his countrie men the Arabians, vnder Heraclius. In the warre he found occa≈øion of principality and power. For when the Arabians being offended with Heraclius for denying them their pay, and for his religion had ≈øeuered them≈øelues from him, Mahomet ioyned him≈øelfe to the angried
≈øouldiers, and ≈øtirred vp their minds again≈øt their Emperour, and encouraged them in their defection. Whereupon, by a certaine company of Souldiers, he was cho≈øen to bee their Captaine (as they commonly are extolled in euery commotion, which fauour the wicked enterpri≈øe of the rebellious people, and ≈øet vpon the mightie, and gouernours.)

In this new Captaine many could not abide the ba≈øene≈ø≈øe of his birth, nor the odiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of his former life, e≈øpecially, they loathed him for a di≈øea≈øe he had, which was the falling ≈øicknes. He therefore to redeeme him≈øelfe from this contempt (which is an ea≈øie matter among the fooli≈øh common people) pretended a diuinitie in his doings, faining him≈øelf to enter communication with God, and ≈øo when he talked with him, to be raui≈øhed out of him≈øelfe, and ≈ø√©emed like vnto one afflicted with the falling ≈øickene≈ø≈øe. And therefore he ≈øaid plainely (but vntruely) how he was no more a Captaine, and Prince elected through the fauour of Souldiers, but a Prophet, and a me≈ø≈øenger of Almighty God, that vnder the ≈øhew of Diuinitie, hee might haue all men the more obedient vnto his words.

But, for as much as he was rude altogether and vnlearned, hee adioyned vnto him≈øelfe two ma≈øters and coun≈øellers that were Chri≈øtians: the one whereof was Sergi ‚Ä¢ s an Arrian, and the other John Ne≈øtorius, to whom there came a third who was a Iew, a Talmudi≈øt. Of which thr√©e, euery one of them defended his ≈øeuerall ≈øect.

Whereupon Mahomet ≈øuppo≈øing that hee ≈øhould not onely gratifie his companions, but al≈øo the more ea≈øily allure all nations vnto him≈øelfe, receiued all, that is: The pertinacie of Arius, the errour of Ne≈øtorius, and the vaine inuentions of the Thalmudi≈øt. And therefore he receiued from the Iew Circumci≈øion; from the Chri≈øtians ≈øundry wa≈øhings, as it were Bapti≈ømes. And with Sergius he denied the Diuinitie of Chri≈øt. Now ≈øome wor≈øhipped Idols, others were Bapti≈øed and ≈øomewhat in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtianitie, who, as ≈øoone as they had left the Romane Emperour for the hatred they bare again≈øt him, renounced foorthwith the Religion which hee defended, euen after the example of tho≈øe ten tribes of I≈ørael, which reuolting from the
hou≈øe of Dauid vnto Ieroboam, 1. King. 12. de≈øpi≈øed the lawes of their Fathers, and went from the ≈øeruice of the onely true God, vnto the innocation of deuils.
Mahomets manner to enlarge and e≈øtabli≈øh his kingdome was this,How the Turks increa≈øed. (which al≈øo his ma≈øters taught him.)

Hee ≈øaid how God at the fir≈øt, to mankind ≈øent Mo≈øes; after him, Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; who were indewed with the power to worke miracles. But men gaue ≈ømall h√©ed to them. Therefore he determined to ≈øend Mahomet, a warrier without miracles, that whom miracles had not mooued, weapons might compell.

Hee ≈øaid, how he was the la≈øt me≈ø≈øenger, and that after him none ≈øhould come; how Chri≈øt in the Go≈øpell had prophecied of him, and how tidings was of him through a wonderfull light, which pa≈ø≈øed from Eua by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of kind through all women, euen to his very mother.

S√©e the ≈øubtiltie of this di≈ø≈øembler and deceiuer Mahomet, who knowing that hee was de≈øtitue altogether of the heauenly gift to worke miracles; hee fained that hee was ≈øent with the ≈øword. But this Armed man at the length was vanqui≈øhed, and receiued a ≈øoare wound in his mouth, whereby he lo≈øt ≈øome of his ch√©eke t√©eth, and was throwen into a ditch, and pu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o a ≈øhamefull foyle, and that, the very day before hee had (from the oracle of God) promi≈øed victorie to him and his. Yea, and while he was yet a common thiefe, he was oftentimes beaten ≈øore of the Drianites, who≈øe Cammels he ≈øet vpon returning from Mecha.
And that Citie which hath him now in honour, ≈øometime adiudged him vnto death, as a very hurtful th√©ef, and appointed a reward if any could bring him vnto them, either quicke or dead.

This champion fir≈øt a th√©efe, afterwards a ≈øeditious ≈øouldier, then a runnagate, after that a Captaine of a rebellious ho≈øte, per≈øwadeth light heads, enemies to the true Religion, how h√©e is the me≈ø≈øenger of God; whereby wee may gather how great the power of Satan is in them, which imbrace not the truth. Whereof it is, that at this day that aduer≈øarie of God defendeth his bla≈øphemies again≈øt God, by Turki≈øh and Mahometicall force, according to the prophecie of Daniel.

div.head: Of Mahomets lawes and eight Commandements.
div.p: AND for the better broaching abroad of his deuili≈øh religions hee hath pre≈øcribed certaine lawes or Commandements, and fortified the ≈øame by Policie.
His lawes are in number eight, which are partly Politicall and party Ceremoniall.
The fir≈øt, concerning God: which is this.
1. God is a great God, and one onely God, and Mahomet is the Prophet of God.

In this Commandement they acknowledge a God; and al≈øo Chri≈øt they acknowledge to be a great Prophet: but deny him to be the Sonne of God, for God (≈øay they) had no wife, and therefore could haue no ≈øonne. But Mahomet they hold to bee a greater Prophet then Chri≈øt, and the la≈øt Prophet of all.

For it is a common ≈øaying among≈øt them, that Abraham was the friend of God, Mo≈øes the me≈ø≈øenger of God, Chri≈øt the breath of God, and that Mahomet was the Prophet of God. They ≈øpeake reuerently of them all foure, and puni≈øh as well tho≈øe that bla≈øpheme Chri≈øt, as tho≈øe that ≈øpeake euill of Mahomet. Yea, they acknowledge Chri≈øt to be the Sonne of the Virgine Mary, but not to haue beene borne according to the common cour≈øe of nature, but to haue proc√©eded from her brea≈øts. And as for his conception by the holy Gho≈øt, they know not what it meaneth; neither doe they know whether there be any holy Gho≈øt or not. But in their praiers they often reiterate the≈øe words together, hu, hu, hu, that is: he, he, he. In de≈øpite of all the Chri≈øtians there is but one God; he, he, he, alone is God. For they hold, becau≈øe we acknowledge thr√©e per≈øons, that therefore wee wor≈øhip thr√©e Gods, and they acknowledge but one God, and are altogether ignorant of the Trinitie in ∆≤nitie, and ∆≤nitie in Trinitie.
The ≈øecond Commandement is, concerning their duety toward their Parents, in the≈øe words.
2. Obey thy parents, and doe nothing to di≈øplea≈øe them, either in word or deed.
How badly this duty is performed among them, I know by experience: for I did neuer read or heare of more di≈øobedient children to their parents, either in word or d√©ed.
The third is concerning their Neighbours, which is this:
3. Doe vnto others as thou woulde≈øt be done vnto thy ≈øelfe.
Some of them are iu≈øt in their dealings one with another: but mo≈øt of them vniu≈øt & deceitfull in their proc√©edings with ≈øtrangers, ≈øome few ≈øhopk√©epers only excepted.
The fourth is concerning praier, wherein is required,
4. That euery man fiue times a day repaire to their Churches, to make publike praier vnto Mahomet.

The Turkes haue no bels, but very faire Churches, and high Steeples; and at the houres of their publike praier they are called to Church by the voice of Criers, who goe vp into their ≈øt√©eples, and cry with a loud voice, Come now and wor≈øhip the great God. And ≈øometimes al≈øo thus: La Illa Eillala, Mahomet Re≈øullala: that is, God is a great God, and Mahomet is his Prophet. And ≈øometimes no more but thus: Ollah hethbar: that is, God is alone: that is, There is but one God. And oftentimes there is but one Crier in one ≈øt√©eple. But on their Sabboth day (which is friday) and at ≈øundry other times, there are many men crying and bauling in euery ≈øt√©eple, like a kennell of hounds when they haue ≈øtarted their game.
The fir≈øt m√©eting at publike praier euery day, is before the ri≈øing of the ≈øunne.
The ≈øecond is about noone or midday, and on their Sabboth day two houres ≈øooner, and againe at noone, ≈øo that they pray fiue times euery day, and on their Sabboth day, ≈øix times.
The third time for publike praier euery day, is at the tenth houre of the day, called by the Turkes, Kindi; by the Moores, A≈ø≈øera, about thr√©e or foure of the clocke after noone.
The fourth m√©eting is about ≈øunne ≈øetting.
The fifth and la≈øt houre of praier, is two houres within night, before they goe to ≈øl√©epe.

Before they come to praier, they prepare them≈øelues thereunto
by outward wa≈øhings of them≈øelues, in token of reuerence, and ≈øuffer no women to come to their Churches, le≈øt the ≈øight of them ≈øhould with-draw their mindes from praier. And though they doe not come to Church, yet when they heare the voice of the Criers, they will pray where≈øoeuer they be, and fall downe and ki≈ø≈øe the ground thr√©e times.

Oftentimes al≈øo the≈øe Criers walke about the ≈øt√©eples in the euenings, and ≈øing (after their rude manner) Dauids P≈øalmes in the Arabicke tongue. And when rich men heare them ≈øing well, and with cl√©ere voices, they are ≈øo delighted therewith, that they v≈øe to ≈øend them money.
Their fifth Commandement is concerning fa≈øting, viz.
5. That one Moone in the yeere, euery one (of any rea≈øonable age) ≈øpend the whole time in fa≈øting.

They haue but one Lent in the y√©ere, and then they fa≈øt generally in this manner: When the new moone changeth, which they call Romadan, then during all that moone, they fa≈øt all the day long betwixt ≈øunne ri≈øing and ≈øunne ≈øetting, and neither eat nor drinke any thing at all. But when the ≈øunne ≈øetteth, then the crier calleth them to Church, and after they haue praied, then they may eat what kinde of meat they will (≈øauing ≈øwines fle≈øh, which is forbidden by their Law) and as oft as they will, vntill ≈øunne ri≈øing: ≈øo that their Lent is but a changing of day into night. During this moone Romadan, they ob≈øerue this kinde of ab≈øtinence very ≈øtrictly. And ≈øo ≈øoone as the next moone changeth, which they call Byram, then their Lent endeth, and they hold a fea≈øt for thr√©e daies ≈øpace together. At which time (they ≈øay) Mahomet deliuered vnto them their law.
Their ≈øixth Commandement is concerning Alme≈ød√©eds.
6. Let euery man, out of his ≈øtore, giue vnto the poore, liberally, freely, and voluntarily.
Their Almes is either publike or priuate.

Their priuate Almes (notwith≈øtanding their Law) is much neglected; for I haue heard of many poore people who haue died
among≈øt them for want of rel√©efe: and in the way as I haue trauelled, I haue found ≈øome dead for hunger and cold. And though a man be neuer ≈øo poore, yet if he be not able to pay his Head money to the King y√©erely, they are beaten, and their women and children ≈øold to pay it. I ‚Ä¢ our murmuring and impatient poore were h√©ere but a ≈øhort time, they would learne to bee more thankfull to God and man, and how to e≈øt√©eme of a benefit be≈øtowed on them, and not cur≈øe and reuile (as many of them doe) if any one that pa≈ø≈øeth by them doe not giue vnto them. The Turkes are more mercifull to birds, cats, and dogs, than to the poore.
Their ≈øeuenth Commandement is concerning Marriage.
7. That euery man mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie marry, to encrea≈øe and multiply the Sect and Religion of Mahomet.

Their cu≈øtome is to buy their wiues of their parents, and neuer to ≈ø√©e them vntil they come to be married: and their marriage is nothing but enrolling in the Cadies booke. Pilawe. for the mo≈øt common di≈øh is Pilaw, which is good ≈øauory meat made of Ri≈øe, and ≈ømall mor≈øels of Mutton boyled therein, and ≈øometimes ro≈øted Buckones, (that is, ≈ømall bits or mor≈øels of fle≈øh.) Their more co≈øtly fare is Sambou≈øes and Muclebites. Sambou≈øes are made of pa≈øte like a great round Pa≈øtie with varietie of hearbes and meates therein, not minced but in Buckones. A Muclebite is a di≈øh made of Egs and hearbs. Their ≈ømaller Sambou≈øes are more common, not ≈øo big as a mans hand, like a ≈øquare Pa≈øtie, with min≈øed meat therein. They haue al≈øo varietie of Helloway, that is, ≈øw√©et meats compounded in ≈øuch ≈øort as are not to be ≈ø√©en el≈øwhere. The poorer ≈øort f√©ed on hearbs and fruites of the tr√©es.Coffa. Their mo≈øt common drinke is Coffa, which is a blacke kind of drinke made of a kind of Pul≈øe like Pea≈øe, called Coaua; which being grownd in the mill, and boiled in water, they drinke it as hot as they can ≈øuffer it; which they find to agr√©e very well with them again≈øt their crudities and f√©eding on hearbs and rawemeates.

Other compound drinkes they haue called Sherbet, made of
water and Sugar, or hony, with ≈ønow therein to make it coole; for although the countrie bee hote, yet they k√©epe ≈ønow all the yeere long to coole their drinke.

It is accounted a great curte≈øie among≈øt them to giue vnto their frends when they come to vi≈øit them, a Fin-ion or Scudella of Coffa, which is more hole≈øome than tooth≈øome, for it cau≈øeth good concoction, and driueth away drow≈øine≈ø≈øe. Some of them will al≈øo drinke Ber≈øh or Opium, which maketh them forget them≈øelues, and talke idly of Ca≈øtles in the ayre, as though they ≈øaw vi≈øions, and heard Reuelations.

Their Coffa hou≈øes are more common than Ale-hou≈øes in England; but they v≈øe not ≈øo much to ≈øit in the hou≈øes as on benches on both ≈øides the ≈øtr√©ets n√©ere vnto a Coffa hou≈øe, euery man with his Fin-ion ful; which being ≈ømoking hot, they v≈øe to put it to their no≈øes & eares, and then ≈øup it off by lea≈øure, being full of idle and Ale-hou≈øe talke whiles they are among≈øt them≈øelues drinking of it; if there be any news, it is talked of there. They haue al≈øo excellent good fountaine waters in mo≈øt places of that countrie, which is a common drinke among≈øt them, e≈øpecially in Sommer time, and in their trauels at all times of the y√©ere.

Some of our Merchants haue weighed their water and ours in England when they haue come home, and haue found their water lighter then ours by foure ounces in the pound; and the lighter the water is, the more plea≈øant it is to drinke, and goeth downe more delectably, as if it were milke rather than water.

In great Cities where the fountaines are either farre off, or not ≈øo plentifull, there are certaine poore men which goe about the ≈øtr√©etes from morning to night with a Beares ≈økinne full of water, ≈øowed vp and fa≈øtened about his ≈øtoulders like a Tinkers budget, with a bole of bra≈ø≈øe in his hand, and offreth water freely to them that pa≈ø≈øe by, except they giue them any thing in curte≈øie, (≈øome ≈øeldom times.)

The greate≈øt part of them are very courteous people among≈øtSalutations of the Turks. them≈øelues, ≈øaluting one another at their m√©etingwith their hand on their bre≈øt (for they neuer vncouer their head) with the≈øe words: Salam Alike Sultanum: that is, peace be vnto you
Sir. Whereunto the other replieth, Alekem Salam, that is: Peace be to you al≈øo. And ≈øometime thus: Elph Marhabba ianum. Or in Turki≈øh thus: Ho≈øh Geldanos, Sophi Geldanos: that is: Welcome my d√©ere friend. And in the morning, Subalkier Sultanum, that is, good morrow Sir: and in the euening thus. Mi≈øalker Sultanum, that is: good euen Sir.

And when friends and acquaintance meet, who haue not ≈ø√©ene one another many dayes before, they ≈øalute one another in Turki≈øh, thus: Neder halen? that is: how doe you? In Arabick thus, I≈øh halac Seedi? that is: How doe you Sir? And I≈øh babtac? that is: how doth thy Gate? (meaning all within his gate) And ≈øo proc√©ed by particulers to a≈øke how doth thy Child, ≈ølaue, hor≈øe, cat, dog, a≈ø≈øe, &c. and euery thing in the hou≈øe, except his wife; for that is held a very vnkind que≈øtion, and not v≈øuall among≈øt them. And if a man come to their hou≈øes, and at the doore enquire of the children for their father, they will an≈øwere him: but if he enquire for the mother, they will throw ≈øtones at him and reuile him.

Their women (as hath b√©ene ≈øhewed before) haue little liberty to come abroad, except it be on the Eue before their Sabbath, (which is Thur≈øday) to w√©epe at the graues of the dead, or to the Bannios or hot Bathes to wa≈øh them≈øelues (as the v≈øe of the contry is.) And when they come abroad, they are alwayes ma≈øked; for it is accounted a ≈øhame for a woman to be ≈ø√©ene bare-faced: yea, they are ≈øo iealous and ≈øu≈øpitious ouer them, that fathers wil not ≈øuffer their owne ≈øonnes, after they come to fouret√©ene y√©eres of age, to ≈ø√©e their mothers.
The≈øe be their common ≈øalutations one to another.
Their more ≈øpeciall ≈øalutations to great per≈øonages are the≈øe.

When a man commeth to ≈øalute the great Turke, or Grand Signior him≈øelfe (into who≈øe pre≈øence few are admitted except Amba≈ø≈øadors and great Per≈øonages) they are led betw√©ene two by the armes, for feare of a ≈øtab, by which meanes one of their Grand Signiors was once killed, and when they returne, they goe backwards; for it is accounted a di≈øgrace to turne their back-parts to a great man. In like manner they ≈øalute their
Ba≈øhawes and other great men, (but not led by the armes) but with their hands on the bre≈øt, bowing downe their heads to ki≈ø≈øe the ≈økirt of his garment, pronouncing the≈øe words, Ollah towal omrac Seedi. That is: God prolong your dayes Sir. And ≈øo long as they talke with a Ba≈øhaw they ≈øtand with their hands on their bre≈øt maiden-like, and bow low at their departure, and goe backward. They neuer vncouer their heads vnto any man, no not to the King him≈øelfe; yea, it is a word of reproach among≈øt them to ≈øay when they mi≈ølike a matter, I had as liue thou ≈øhewed≈øt me thy bare head.

They call one another diuer≈øly, and not alwaies by their names, but ≈øometimes by their fathers Calling, trade, or degr√©e: as Eben Sultan, that is, The ≈øonne of a King: Eben Terzi, The ≈øonne of a Tailor.
And ≈øometimes by their father qualities, as Eben Sacran, that is, The ≈øonne of a Drunkard.
And ≈øometimes by their markes, as Colac cis, that is, A man without eares: Cow≈øi Sepher, that is Sepher with the thinne beard.
And ≈øometimes by their Stature, as Tow-ill, that is, A tall man: Sgire rugiall, that is, A little man.
And ≈øometimes by their Offices, as I-a≈øgee, that is, A Secretarie: Nibe, that is, A Clerke, &c.
And ≈øometimes by their humours, as Chiplac, that is, A naked man; Or, One who was of a humour to weare no cloathes but breeches.

But their common word of curte≈øie either to ≈øtrangers, or ≈øuch who≈øe names they know not, or whom they purpo≈øe to reuerence, is Chillabee, that is, Gentleman. And there is no man among≈øt them of any degr√©e, will refu≈øe to an≈øwer to any of the≈øe names. But if nature haue marked them either with gogle eies, bunch backes, lame legs, or any other infirmitie or deformitie, as they are knowen by it, ≈øo they are content to b√©e called by it.

But they that haue gone on pilgrimage to their holy Citie Mecha, where their Prophet Mahomet was buried, at their returne are called Hogies, that is, Pilgrimes, as Hogie Tahar,
Hogie Mahammet, &c. which is counted a word of great grace and credit among≈øt them. And the witne≈ø≈øe of an Hogie will be taken before any other.

div.head: Of the Arabians.
div.p: TThere are al≈øo many Arabians in Aleppo, called vulgarly, Arabs or Bedweens. They cal them≈øelues Saracens, of Sara; but they are rather I≈øhmalites, of I≈øhmael Abrahams ≈øonne by Hagar, and therefore al≈øo called Hagarens. But ≈øome take them to be of the race of the Sabaeans, which were wilde and ≈øauage people, of Sabaea, a Country in the middle of Arabia, towards the Ea≈øt, enuironed with great Rocks, where is great ≈øtore of Cynnomon and Ca≈øia, Frankincen≈øe and Myrrh, which people came of Sheba, nephew to Ketura and Abraham. Their natiue Country was Arabia, a Country in A≈øia, betw√©ene Iudaea and Egypt, ≈øo called of Arabus the ≈øonne of Apollo. It is diuided into thr√©e Regions, which are the≈øe, Arabia Petrea, Arabia De≈øerta, and Arabia Foelix. But at this day they haue no certaine Country or place of abode, but wander vp and downe thorowout all Syria, A≈ø≈øyria, Gallely, Iudaea, Pale≈øtina, and Egypt. And as in Iobs tune they liued by theft and robberie and ≈øpoile of men, ≈øo doe they al≈øo to this pre≈øent day. They haue two Kings at this day, viz. Dandan and Abori≈øha; the one their lawfull King, the other an V≈øurper; and ≈øome follow the one, and ≈øome the other, and are bitter enemies one to another; yet haue I ≈øeldome heard of any great wars betwixt them, for they ≈øeldome m√©et. They neuer come into any walled Townes or Cities, for feare of trea≈øon: but liue in tents, and are h√©ere to day, and many hundred miles off within few daies after.

They are a ba≈øe, beggerly, and rogi≈øh people; wandering vp and downe, and liuing by ≈øpoile, which they account no ≈øinne, becau≈øe they are Mahomets Countrimen, and he allowed them liberty to liue by theft. Yet their Kings doe no great harme, but take toule or tribute of the Carauans as they pa≈ø≈øe by, which if they pay willingly, they pa≈ø≈øe quietly, and are not robbed, but a little exacted vpon.

One of their Kings hath often times pitched his tents n√©ere vnto the City of Aleppo, and many Merchants being de≈øirous to ≈øee them and their order, tooke occa≈øion to pre≈øent him with ≈øome ≈ømall pre≈øent or other, which he tooke very kindly, and admitted them to his table, and gaue them a tent to lodge in all night: on the morrow for breakfa≈øt one of them made him a min≈øed pie, and ≈øet it before him hot as it came out of the ouen: But as Diogines accu≈øtomed to f√©ed on roots, hauing a p√©ece of a tart giuen him to eat, and as he was eating it, being a≈øked what it was, an≈øwered that it was bread; and when he was laughed at for his an≈øwer, he ≈øaid again, Either it is bread of a very good making, or bread very wel handled in the baking: So this Synicall or Diogenicall King accu≈øtomed to f√©ed gro≈øly, hauing neuer ≈ø√©ene a pie or pa≈øtie before, maruelled what it was: And when he ≈øaw it cut vp and opened, and perceiued ≈ømoke to com√® out of it, ≈øhrunke backe, fearing it had b√©ene ≈øome engine to de≈øtroy him, and that the fire would follow after the ≈ømoke. But when he perceiued no fire followed the ≈ømoke, he was content to ta≈øte of it, and highly commended it, as the daintie≈øt di≈øh that euer he ta≈øted of in his life.

The≈øe Arabian Kings neuer k√©epe any money in their pur≈øes, but ≈øpend it as fa≈øt as they finde it, and when they want, with their ≈øword they ≈ø√©eke a new purcha≈øe. Some are ≈øouldiers, fighting faithfully on any ≈øide that will giue them pay. Some of this rogi≈øh Arabian race follow neither of their Kings, but wander from place to place in caues and rocks, and liue by their ≈øword, not only robbing, but killing ≈øuch as they can ouercome. Others of them (of a better minde) ≈øoiourne in Cities of trade and trafficke, and make them≈øelues ≈øeruants to any Nation that will ≈øet them on worke, and well reward them. Some of them are hor≈øe-k√©epers, ≈øome Ba≈øtages, that is, Porters, and ≈øome vnder-cookes in kitchins, and are very ≈øeruiceable. But for the mo≈øt part their lodgings are on ≈øome dunghill or other, or odde corner of the City, with ≈øome ≈øilly tent ouer their heads. Their wiues weare rings in their no≈øes, either of ≈øiluer or bra≈ø≈øe, fa≈øtned to the middle gri≈øtle of their no≈øe, and colour their lips blew with Indico, and goe alwaies bare legged and
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , with „Äà‚óä„Äâ or rings of bra≈ø≈øe aboe their ancles and bracelets of bra≈ø≈øe abou ‚Ä¢ their hands. They are people which can and doe „Äà‚óä„Äâ goe at „Äà‚óä„Äâ and mi≈øerie, both for diet and lodging. Their women are ≈økilfull in mourning and crying by art, and therefore they are hired to cry at the funerals of Turkes and Moores oftentimes, tearing their haire, and making all their face blew with Indico; The chiefe≈øt thing that I haue ob≈øerued in them, worth prai≈øe, is this, that they retaine the v≈øe of ≈øpeaking their naturall tongue to this day, ≈øpeaking the Arabicke naturally, which is a farre more learned language than the Turki≈øh: for as the Turkes Religion is a mixed Religion, compounded of many Religions; ≈øo is their language al≈øo a medly language, or (as I may iu≈øtly call it) a linke wolfie Religion and language, compounded of many other languages, wherein nothing is written. But the Arabian tongue is a learned language, wherein Aui ‚Ä¢ en and many learned Phy≈øitians haue written much, and to this day the Turkes Alcoran and all their Law and Religion is written in the Arabicke tongue, which is one of tho≈øe Orientall Languages which depend on the Hebrue tongue, wherin becau≈øe you haue ≈øome knowledge, and are ≈øtudious in the tongues, (according to your reque≈øt in your la≈øt letters) I will √†cquaint you what languages are h√©ere ≈øpoken, and which languages are mo≈øt common and commendable to trauellers to goe furthe≈øt withall. There are h√©ere ≈øpoken ≈øo many ≈øeuerall languages as there are ≈øeuerall Nations h√©ere dwelling or ≈øoiourning, euery Nation (among≈øt them≈øelues) ≈øpeaking their owne language. And h√©ere are of mo≈øt Nations in the world ≈øome, who either come with their Merchandi≈øe to ≈øell or by commodities, or ≈øoiourne h√©ere as ≈øtrangers, or el≈øe haue acce≈ø≈øe, and rece≈ø≈øe to this City as trauellers. But of all Chri≈øtian languages, the Italian tongue is mo≈øt v≈øed, and therewithall a man may trauell furthe≈øt. But of all the Orientoll tongues, the≈øe foure are mo≈øt ≈øpoken in the≈øe parts, Arabicke, Turki≈øh, Armenian, and Per≈øian, or Agime≈øco: Of euerie one of which languages (that you may ≈ø√©e how they differ) I will ≈øhew you how they number from one to twenty, to ≈øati≈øfie your expectation.

div.head: Of the Jewes.
div.p: BE≈øides all the≈øe Mahometans (which I haue already named) there are many Iewes in Con≈øtantinople, Aleppo, Dama≈øcus, Babylon, Grand Cayro, and euery great Citie and place of Marchandi≈øe throughout all the Turkes dominions, who are knowne by their hatts: for they were accu≈øtomed to weare red hatts without br ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mes at my fir≈øt comming: But lately (the head Vizier being their enemy) they are con≈øtrained to weare hatts of blewe cloth, becau≈øe red was accounted too ≈øtately and princelike a colour for them to weare.

They are called by three names, which were giuen to them of old. Fir≈øt, they are called Hebrewes, (as ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe) of Heber the fourth from Noah, in whom the hebrew tongue remained at the confu≈øion of tongues, whence he had his name. But S. Augu≈øtine and other fathers affirme, that they were fir≈øt called Hebreweof Abraham, with the alteration of a fewe letters, Hebraei qua≈øi Abrahaei, that is, Hebrewes as it were Abrahites.
Secondly they were called I≈øraelites from Jacob ≈øurnamed I≈ørael, who≈øe grandfathers Abraham was.

Thirdly, they were called Iewes, after that Juda and Beniamin (which for the vnity of minds were (as it were one Tribe) following Rehoboam the ≈øonne of Solomon of the tribe of Iuda, made the kingdome of Iuda. The other ten betaking them to Ieroboam of the tribe of Ephraim, ≈øet vp the kingdome of the Ephramites or I≈ørael. And what became of tho≈øe ten tribes, the Iewes acknowledge them≈øelues to be ignorant. Only ≈øome of their Rabbies thinke them to bee in Tarracia: the onely rea≈øon which I haue heard them alledge for their opinion is this, becau≈øe they often vnder≈øtand by Tartarians who came from thence to v≈øe marchandi≈øe in Aleppo and el≈øe where, that there are many among≈øt them called by Hebrew names to this day. Of the≈øe thr√©e names whereby they are knowne, the mo≈øt common name whereby they are called at this day is, the name of Iewes. One and the ≈øame people thrice changed their names, & often the place of their abode: And to this day they haue no
king nor country proper to them≈øelues, but are di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole world, and in euery place where they come, they are contemptible and of ba≈øe account,Matth. 27. 25. according to the cry of tho≈øe crucifiers. His blood bee vpon vs and our children, which is fulfilled this day in our eares and eies. They are of more vile account in the ≈øight of Turkes then Chri≈øtians; in ≈øo much that if a Iewe would turne Turke, he mu≈øt fir≈øt turne Chri≈øtian before they will admit him to be a Turke. Yea, it is a word of reproach among≈øt the Turkes, & a v≈øuall prote≈øtation among≈øt them, when they are fal≈øly accu≈øed of any crime, to cleare them≈øelues they v≈øe to prote≈øt in this manner, If this be true; then God graunt I may die a Iewe, And the Iewes in like ca≈øes v≈øe to ≈øay, If this be not a fal≈øe accu≈øation, then God graunt I may dye a Chri≈øtian, praying better for them≈øelues then they belieue, and as all of them mu≈øt be that ≈øhall bee ≈øaued. And the poore Chri≈øtians ≈øoiourning and dwelling in the≈øe partes doe hate them very vncharitably and irreligiou≈øly: (in that we read Rom. 11. many arguments prouing that they ≈øhall bee conuerted againe.) for on good fryday in many places (e≈øpecially at Zante) they throw ≈øtones at them, in≈øomuch that they dare not come out of their hou≈øes all that day, and yet are ≈øcar≈øe in ≈øafety in their hou≈øes, for they v≈øe to throw ≈øtones at their windowes and dores, and on the roofe of their hou≈øes. On thru≈øday about noone, the Iewes begin to k√©epe within dores, and continue there with their dores ≈øhut vntil ≈øaturday about noone, for if they come forth before that time they are ≈øure to be ≈øtoned, but after noone on Ea≈øter eue if they come abroad, they may pa≈ø≈øe as quietly as euer they did. The≈øe in their blinde zeale thinke to be reuenged on them for whom Chri≈øt prayed ≈øaying, Father forgiue them, for they know not what they doe.

And ≈øome ignorant Chri≈øtians refu≈øe to eat of their meat or bread: their rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Iewes refu≈øe to eat or drinke with Chri≈øtians to this day, or to eat any meat that Chri≈øtians kill. But it is not vnu≈øuall among≈øt Chri≈øtians of better knowledge, to eat of the Jewes meat, which ordinarily they buy of them: for the Iewes to this day eat not of the hinderpart of any
bea≈øt, but only of the former parts, and ≈øell the hinder quarters of their b√©efe, mutton, kids, goats, &c. to Chri≈øtians.

They ob≈øerue ≈øtill all their old Ceremonies and fea≈øts, Sacrifices only excepted, which the Turkes will not ≈øuffer them to doe: for they were wont among≈øt them to ≈øacrifice children, but dare not now for feare of the Turkes. Yet ≈øome of them haue confe≈ø≈øed, that their Phy≈øitians kill ≈øome Chri≈øtian patient or other, whom they haue vnder their hands at that time, in ≈øtead of a ≈øacrifice.

If a man die without children, the next brother taketh his wife, and rai≈øeth vp ≈ø√©ed vnto his brother: and they ≈øtill marry in their owne kindred. Many of them are rich Merchants: ≈øome of them Drogomen, and ≈øome Brokers. Mo≈øt of them are very crafty and deceitfull people. They haue no beggers among≈øt them, but many th√©eues, and ≈øome who ≈øteale for nece≈ø≈øity, becau≈øe they dare not begge.

They are al≈øo very great V≈øurers, and therein the Turkes ecell them: for although there be V≈øurers among≈øt them, yet they allow it not: for if a Chri≈øtian or any man borrow money of a Turke (though he promi≈øe him intere≈øt) yet if he pay the principall, he dares not mole≈øt him for intere≈øt, nor complaine of him, being again≈øt their law.

The Iewes Sabboth is on Saturday, which they ob≈øerue ≈øo ≈øtrictly, that they will not trauell vpon any occa≈øion on that day, nor receiue money, nor handle a pen to write, (as I haue knowen by experience in a Doctor of Phy≈øicke:) but on the morrow he would take double f√©es of his Patient.

They read their law in the Hebrue tongue, written in Phylacteries or long roles of parchment. And the Old Te≈øtament is al≈øo read in the Hebrue. But their Cakams and Cohens preach in the Spani≈øh tongue. All matters of controuer≈øie betwixt them≈øelues are brought before their Cakam to decide, who is their chiefe Churchman. Cakam in Hebrue is as much as Sapiens in Latine, that is, a wi≈øe man: and Cohen in Hebrue is as much as Sacerdos in Latine, that is, a Prie≈øt.

I haue ≈øundry times had conference with many of them; and ≈øome of them, yea the greate≈øt part of them, are bla≈øphemous wretches, who (when they are pre≈ø≈øed with an argument which they cannot an≈øwer) breake out into opprobrious ≈øp√©eches, and ≈øay Chri≈øt was a fal≈øe Prophet, and that his Di≈øciples ≈øtole him out of his graue whiles the ≈øouldiers (who watched him) ≈ølept: and that their forefathers did de≈øeruedly crucifie him; and that if he were now liuing, they would v≈øe him wor≈øe than euer then forefathers did.

div.head: Of Chri≈øtians of ≈øundry ≈øorts ≈øoiourning in Aleppo.
div.p: Be≈øides the≈øe Turkes, Moores, and Arabians, (which are all Mahometans) and Iewes (which are Talmudi≈øts) there are al≈øo ≈øundry ≈øorts of Chri≈øtians in this Countrey, which are of two ≈øorts, either ≈øuch as were borne, brought vp, and dwelled in the Country, or ≈øuch as were borne in Chri≈øtendome, and only ≈øoiourne h√©ere for a time to exerci≈øe merchandi≈øes.

The fir≈øt ≈øort who were borne in this Heathen Countrey, and dwell there, are either Armenians, Maronites, Iacobites, Georgians, Chelfalines, or Greekes; which are all gouerned by their Patriarkes for Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters. But for ciuill gouernment, both they and their Patriarkes are ≈øubiect to Turki≈øh Lawes, yea they are all ≈ølaues vnto the great Turk, whom they call their Grand Signior.

div.head: Of the No≈øtranes or Nazaritans.
div.p:
Among≈øt all the≈øe ≈øorts of Chri≈øtians, there is among≈øt the M ‚Ä¢ ronites an ancient / company of Chri≈øtians, called vulgarly
No≈øtranes, qua≈øi Nazaritans, of the Sect of the Nazarites, more ciuill and harmle≈ø≈øe people than any of the re≈øt. Their Country is Mount Lybanus (as I wrote vnto you h√©eretofore) but many of them dwell at Aleppo, whereof ≈øome of them are Ca≈ø≈øi≈øes, that is, Churchmen; ≈øome of them are Cookes, and ≈øeruants vnto Engli≈øh Merchants and others; ≈øome Artificers: All of them liue ≈øomewhat poorely, but they are more hone≈øt and true in their conuer≈øation than any of the re≈øt, e≈øpecially at their fir≈øt comming from Mount Lybanus to dwell in Aleppo; and many during their continuance there, if they be not corrupted by other wicked Nations there dwelling: in whom I ob≈øerued more by experience than I heard of them, or noted in them when I was among≈øt them at Mount Lybanus. And e≈øpecially for the manner of their marriage, and how they honour the ≈øame.

They buy their wiues of their fathers (as others there dwelling, doe) but neuer ≈ø√©e them vntill they come to be married, nor then neither vntill the mariage be ≈øolemnized betwixt them: for there is a partition in the place where they m√©et to be married, and the man and his friends ≈øtand on the one ≈øide, and the yoong woman & her friends on the other ≈øide, where they may heare, but not ≈ø√©e one another, vntill the Ca≈ø≈øies bid the yoong man put his hand thorow an hole in the wall, and take his wife by the hand. And whiles they haue hand in hand, the mother of the maid commeth with ≈øome ≈øharpe in≈øtrument made for the purpo≈øe, and all to bepricketh the new married mans hand, and maketh it bl√©ed. And if he let her hand goe when he f√©eleth his hand ≈ømart, they hold it for a ≈øigne that he will not loue her: But if he hold fa≈øt (notwith≈øtanding the ≈ømart) and wring her hard by the hand vntill ≈øhe cry, rather than he will once ≈øhrinke, then he is counted a louing man, and her friends are glad that they haue be≈øtowed her on him.

And how they honour marriage aboue others, I ob≈øerued by the naming of their fir≈øt manchilde. For as among≈øt vs the women, when they are married, lo≈øe their Surnames, and are ≈øurnamed by the hu≈øbands ≈øurname, and children likewi≈øe; ≈øo among≈øt them the father lo≈øeth his name, and is called by the name of his elde≈øt ≈øonne, in this manner. I haue knowen a
No≈øtrane who≈øe name was Mou-≈øe, that is, Mo≈øes, who hauing a manchilde, named him V≈øeph, that is, Io≈øeph, and then was the father no more called Mou ‚Ä¢ e, Mo ‚Ä¢ es, but Abou V≈øeph, that is, the father of Io≈øeph. Another who≈øe name was V≈øeph, named his elde≈øt ≈øonne Pher-iolla, after which he was no more called V ‚Ä¢ eph, but Abou Ph ‚Ä¢ r-iolla, the father of Pher-iolla. Another man called Iubraell, that is, Gabriell, his ≈øonne at the time of Bapti≈øme being named Mou≈øe, he alwaies after was called Abou Mou≈øe, that is, the father of Mo≈øes: ≈øuch an honour doe they account it to be father of a manchilde.

The≈øe No≈øtranes reuerence their Ca≈ø≈øi≈øes greatly, and ki≈ø≈øe their hand where≈øoeuer they m√©et them: yet are mo≈øt of them altogether vnlearned, hauing only the knowledge of the Syriac tongue, wherein their Liturgie is read.

They k√©epe their Fea≈øts at the ≈øame time as we doe, viz. Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe, Ea≈øter, and Whit≈øuntide: and at Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe on the Twelfth day in the morning, called Epiphanie, their yoong men haue a cu≈øtome (betimes in the morning) to leape naked into the water: I could neuer heare any rea≈øon of their ≈øo doing, but Vzan≈øa de prea≈øe, the Cu≈øtome of their Countrey. And though it be then very cold, yet they per≈øwade them≈øelues and others, that then it is hotter than at any other time, and that the water then hath an extraordinarie vertue to wa≈øh away their ≈øinnes.
On Munday in Ea≈øter w√©eke and Whit≈øun w√©eke, the≈øe No≈øtranes goe with their Ca≈ø≈øi≈øes to the graues of the dead, and there kn√©ele downe, and burne incen≈øe, and pray at euery graue.

div.head: Of the Chelfalines.
div.p:
THe Chelfalines are Chri≈øtians, dwelling vpon the borders of Per≈øia, betw√©ene Me≈øopotamia and Per≈øia, at a place called Chel≈øa. The≈øe bring ≈øilke to Aleppo to ≈øell. They are plai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
dealing people. If a man pay them money, and (by ouer-reckoning him≈øelfe) giue them more than their due, though there
be but one peece ouer, ≈øo ≈øoone as they perceiue it, though it b√©e many daies after, they will bring it backe againe, and re≈øtore it, and thinke they ≈øhall neuer returne ≈øafely into their Country, if they ≈øhould not make re≈øtitution thereof. The≈øe people per≈øwade them≈øelues, and report vnto others, that they dwell in that place which was called Eden, whereinto Adam was put to keepe it and dre≈ø≈øe it. But ≈øome hold that this plea≈øant garden Eden did extend ouer all the earth. But by the ≈øecond chapter of Gene≈øis it appeareth manife≈øtly, that this garden wherein man was placed, which we call Paradi≈øe, was a certaine place on earth, not ≈øpreading ouer all, but only a part thereof, containing a conuenient portion of the Countrey called Eden, bounding vpon the Riuer Euphrates‚ñ™ which Riuer is deuided into foure ≈øtreames, and runneth (or at lea≈øtwi≈øe did then flow) in manner as it is de≈øcribed, Gen. 2. 10. &c. And Eden is the name of a Country, ≈øo called for the plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of it. For Hadan in Hebrue, is in Engli≈øh to delight. From hence al≈øo the Greekes call plea≈øure, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .

And how≈øoeuer it be≈øomewhat probable, that the≈øe Chelphalines dwell now in that Country which was called Eden, yet Plato, and Ari≈øto ‚Ä¢ le, and Lactantius, and others, doe con≈øtantly affirme (as they haue receiued of ancient monuments) that Mountaines, and Riuers, and Ilands, and Countries, haue receiued much alteration in this kinde. Sicilia is ≈øaid to haue beene diuided from Italy, Cyprus from Syria, England from France, by the violence of the Sea, whereas before they were ioined, as Pelo ‚Ä¢ onne ‚Ä¢ us is to the re≈øt of Grecia, or as the towne of Rye (at an high water) ≈ø√©emeth to be to the re≈øt of England: So that no certainty can be giuen either by reading, or trauelling, of the place where Eden was, becau≈øe the≈øe Riuers run in other ≈øtreames: fora≈ømuch as Cyrus, at the taking of Babylon, is affirmed to haue re≈øtrained the maine chanell of this very riuer Euphrates, vnto an vnwonted cour≈øe; and to haue deuided the riuer Gindes (which is next vnto it in greatne≈ø≈øe) into 360. ≈øtreames. Be≈øides, the Country of Me≈øopotamia, by which the≈øe riuers pa≈ø≈øe, being partly dry and ≈øandy, and ≈øeldome watered with the ≈øhowers of heauen; and on the other part, exc√©eding
fruitfull by the nature of the ≈øoile; is (by the indu≈øtry of the inhabitants) ≈øo nouri≈øhed with waters, by cutting out chanels and ditches out of the maine ≈øtreames, as the ≈øame is amended, where it is barren, of the ≈øame vnfruitfulne≈ø≈øe; and corrected againe of his ouerrich increa≈øe, where it is ouer fertile. No maruell therefore if the≈øe riuers are not fully agreed vpon by Writers, hauing lo≈øt perhaps their ancient ≈øtreames, together with their names, as Paradi≈øe, and the whole earth be≈øides ha≈øh lo≈øt her ancient fruitfulne≈ø≈øe.

And the≈øe Chelphalines are ignorant people, and haue no rea≈øon to prooue that they now dwell in the place which was called Eden, whereinto Adam was put to k√©epe it and to dre≈ø≈øe it, but that the riuer Euphrates, and other riuers (mentioned Gen. 2. 10. 11. 12.) run by their Country.

Others of them ≈øay, that they haue receiued it by Tradition from their Elders, from time to time. But that which God hath concealed, I will not ≈øearch out. But (notwith≈øtanding all that I haue read, heard, or ≈ø√©ene in my trauels) I re≈øolue my ≈øelfe, that no man liuing can demon≈øtrate the place, which God (for the ≈øinnes of Adam) accur≈øed; and euer ≈øince, the place is vnknowen.

div.head: Of the Greekes.
div.p: THe Greekes are a very ≈øuper≈øtitious, ≈øubtle, and deceitfull people, in≈øomuch that it is growen to a prouerbe among≈øt the Italians,
That is,

q.l: He that tru≈øteth to a Greeke,
Shall be int ‚Ä¢ eaged, and ≈øtill to ≈øeeke.

div.p: They hate the Papi≈øts, and yet in many things agr√©e with them, as in Auricular Confe≈ø≈øion, Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, and ≈øome other opinions. But their Liturgie is read in the vulgar Tongue.

The Greeke in Aleppo are very poore, for they are there (for the mo≈øt p ‚Ä¢ rt) but Brokers or Ba≈øtages, that is, Porters‚ñ™ and many of their women as light as water, maintaining their hu≈øbands,
them≈øelues and their families, by pro≈øtituting their bodies to others. And their owne hu≈øbands are often times their Pandars or procurers to bring them Cu≈øt ‚Ä¢ mers.

But the Greekes that liue at Con≈øtantinople are many of them great Merchants, and very rich; but exc√©eding proud, and ≈øumptuous in apparell, euen the ba≈øe≈øt of them, and e≈øpecially their women, who though they be but Coblers wiues, or poore Artificers wiues, yet they goe in gownes of ≈øattin, and taffery, yea of cloth of ≈øiluer and gold, adorned with precious ≈øtones, and many gemmes and iewels about their necks and hands. They care not how they pinch their bellies, ≈øo that they may haue fine apparell on their backs. And at the time of their marriage, the women condition with their hu≈øbands to finde them decent apparell, and con ‚Ä¢ enient diet, and bring them before their Patriarke of Con≈øtantinople to confirme it; which, if it be not performed accordingly, if they complaine to their Patriarke, they are diuorced pre≈øently, and ≈øhee taketh an other man to her hu≈øband, better able to maintaine her: and he may marry an other woman if he plea≈øe.
One onely in≈øtance hereof will I giue you in a matter notoriou≈øly knowen to all nations ≈øoiourning or dwelling in or about Con≈øtantinople.

In Pera or Gallata (on the other fide the water) there is a mo≈øt famous (or rather infamous) Gr√©eke whore called Charatza Sophia, that is, Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe Sophia, (the daughter of a poore Gr√©eke widow who liueth by laundry) who being maried v ‚Ä¢ to a G√©eke, becau≈øe he kept her not fine enough, ≈øhe complaned of him to the Patriarke, and was diuorced from him; and pre≈øently thereupon tooke another man, who was a Chri≈øtian in name, but no Gr√©eke, but one who was (as is reported of him) borne in no land in the world, but by ≈øea, and brought vp in Polonia vntill he were thirt√©ene or fourt√©ene n√©eres of age, and then came to Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øerued many ma≈øters there, at the fir≈øt in the ba≈øe≈øt ≈øeruices, both in the ≈øtable, and in the kitchin, and afterwards in better ≈øeruices than he de≈øerued, being both vnlearned and irreligious.

This man had many children by this infamous woman Sophia:
yet after many yee ‚Ä¢ es (ari≈øing to higher fortunes) turned her away, and married another woman: And (to dawbe vp the matter ≈øomwhat ≈ømoothly) procured a Greeke Taylor to marry with this Sophia and gaue many hundred Dolers with her to her marriage. But this Charatza could not content her ≈øelfe long with this Gr√©eke Taylor, but admitted dayly other men into her companie, whereupon the poore Taylor ran away with his money, and left this light hu≈øwife to the mercie of her former louers, hauing thr√©e hu≈øbands liuing, yet ≈øhee her ≈øelfe liuing with none of them. This is common in euery mans mouth thereabouts, and talked of many thou≈øand miles off, to the di≈øgrace of his Countrie, and ≈ølander of Chri≈øtianitie.

And both at Con≈øtantinople, Aleppo, and other places of Turkey where there is traffiking and trading of Merchants, it is no rare matter for popi≈øh Chri≈øtians of ≈øundry other Countries, to Cut Cabine, (as they call it) that is: to take any woman of that contrie where they ≈øoiourne, (Turki≈øh women onely excepted, for it is death for a Chri≈øtian to meddle with them) and when they haue bought them, and enroled them in the Cadies booke, to v≈øe them as wiues ≈øo long as they ≈øoiourne in that countrie, and maintaine them gallantly, to the con≈øuming of their wealth, dimini≈øhing of their health, and endangering of their owne ≈øoules. And when they depart out of that Country, they ≈øhake off the≈øe their ≈øw√©et-hearts, & leaue them to ≈øhift for them≈øelues and their children. And this they account no ≈øinne, or at lea≈øt wi≈øe ≈øuch a ≈øinne as may be wa≈øhed away with a litle holy water.

And the≈øe are the vertues which many Chri≈øtians learne by ≈øoiourning long in Heathen Countries: which is not to be maruelled at; for if Io≈øeph (a good man) liuing in Pharaoh his Court, had learned to ≈øweare by the life of Pharaoh; and Peter (a great Apo≈øtle) being in the high Prie≈øts hall but once, denied Chri≈øt thrice; we may well thinke that they which dwell long in wicked Countries, and conuer≈øe with wicked men, are ≈øomewhat tainted with their ≈øinnes, if not altogether ≈øowred with the leauen of their vngodline≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Of tho≈øe whom they call Franks or Freemen, ≈øoiourning in Aleppo.
div.p: THE other ≈øortes of Chri≈øtians liuing in Aleppo are ≈øuch as are borne in other parts of Chri≈øtendome, and onely ≈øoiourne there for a time to v≈øe trafficke and trade in merchandi≈øe, and the≈øe are Engli≈øhmen, Italians, Frenchmen, Dutchmen, and others, whom they call by a generall name Frangi, that is, Franks, or Fr√©emen. For all the re≈øt, euen from the greate≈øt Ba≈øhaw or Vizier vnto the poore≈øt pea≈øant, are ≈ølaues vnto the Grand Signiour, who onely is free; and all the ‚Ä¢ e≈øt are borne, brought vp, liue and die his ≈ølaues: for the Grand Signiour can commaund the head of any one of them at his plea≈øure.

Yea, if ≈øome great Vizier or Ba≈øhawe to whom he hath committed the gouernement of ≈øome Citie or countrie, fall into his di≈øfauour, if he ≈øend but a Cappagie, that is, a Pur ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ to him with his writing, with a blacke ≈øeale in a blacke boxe, none of them all dare with≈øtand him, but ≈øuffer this ba≈øe C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ppagie to ≈øtrangle him: though it be in the hou≈øe before his wiues, children and ≈øeruants, yet none dare lift vp their hands again≈øt him.

There was a Ba≈øhawe of Aleppo, who gouerned the Citie and Countrie adioyning, who was in the di≈øfauour of the King, and the King ≈øent a Cappagie to ≈øtrangle him, who inquiring for the Ba≈øhaws hou≈øe at A ‚Ä¢ eppo. and vnder≈øtanding he was at his Garden foure miles from the Citie, he rode and met him in the way, and opened his black box and ≈øhewed him his commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øtrangle him, whereat his countenance changed, and he only craued this fauour, that hee might haue libertie to ≈øay his Praiers before he died: which performed, hee y√©eldeth his head and was ≈øtrangled, ≈øitting on his hor≈øe before all his followers, which were at the lea≈øt 10 ‚Ä¢ . men, and no man dur≈øt ≈øpeake one worde again≈øt it, much le≈ø≈øe offer to re≈øi≈øt him, but ≈øaid, it was Gods will it ≈øhould be ≈øo.

And not onely the great Turke doeth thus tyrannize ouer
his ≈ølaues, but euery Ba≈øhaw who hath gouernment ouer others in a Citie or Countrie, tyranni≈øe ouer tho≈øe which are vnder their regiment, and ≈øometimes ≈øtrangled, ≈øometimes beheaded, and ≈øometines put vnto terrible tortures tho≈øe who offend. Yea, oftentimes without offen≈øe; onely becau≈øe they are rich and haue faire hou≈øes the Ba≈øhaw will lay to their charge ≈øuch things as he him≈øelfe knoweth to be vntrue, and put them to death that he may ≈øeaze vpon his goods.

There was a Sherife or a Green-headin Aleppo, whom they account Mahomets kinred, who offending the Ba≈øhaw and brauing him in tearmes as thogh he dur≈øt not puni≈øh him, he cau≈øed one of his officers to goe with him home, and when hee came before his owne doore, openly in the ≈øtreet to break both his legs and armes, & there let him lie, and no man dur≈øt finde fault, or giue him food; or Phy≈øician, or Chirurgion come to him; or wife or ≈øeruants take him into hou≈øe, but there he lay all day, and ≈øhould ≈øo haue continued vntill he had died for hunger, or dogs eaten him, had not his friends giuen money to the Ba≈øhaw to haue his throat cut to rid him out of his paine. And this is a common puni≈øhment amon≈øt them.

And ≈øomtimes for ≈ømall offen≈øes, they will lay a man downe on his backe, and hoy≈øe vp his f√©ete, and with a cudgell giue them 300. or 400. blowes on the ≈øoles of their f√©ete, whereby manie are lamed.
And ≈øome they ≈øet on a ≈øharpe ≈øtake naked, which commeth from his fundament vp to his mouth, if he find not fauour to haue his throat cut ≈øooner.

And ≈øome are ganched in this manner; they are drawen vp by a rope fa≈øtened about their armes to the top of a Gazouke or Gibbet full of hookes, and let downwards againe, and on what part ≈øoeuer any hooke taketh hold, by that they hang vntill they die for hunger.

And ≈øome in like ≈øort are drawen ouer a Gibbet, and they being compa≈ø≈øed about the naked wa≈øte with a ≈ømall coard, the coard is drawen by 2. men to make them draw vp their breath, and ≈øtill pulled ≈øtraiter and ≈øtraiter, vntill they bee ≈øo narow in the wa≈øte, that they may ea≈øily be cut off by the middle at one
blow, and then the vpper part is let downe on a hot grid-iron and there ≈øeared vp, to k√©epe them in ≈øen≈øe and feeling of paine ≈øo long as is po≈ø≈øible, and the neather part is throwen to the dogges, &c.
Vn≈øpeakeable is their tyranny to tho≈øe that fall into their hands, not vnlike the tyrannie of the Spaniards towards the poore Indians who neuer offend them.

They, whom they call Franks or Fr√©emen, liue in greater ≈øecuritie among≈øt them then their owne people, by rea≈øon that they are gouerned by Con≈øuls of their owne nation, and tho≈øe Con≈øuls al≈øo are backed by Amba≈ø≈øadours for the ≈øame nations which are alwaies Leige ‚Ä¢ s at Con≈øtantinople: and when their Con≈øuls abroad are offered wrong, they write vnto the Amba≈ø≈øadours, how, and by whom they are wronged: and then the Amba≈ø≈øadour procureth from the great Turk commandements to the Ba≈øhaw of Aleppo to redre≈ø≈øe their wrongs, and puni≈øh ≈øuch as offend them. Otherwi≈øe there were no dwelling for Franks among≈øt them, but they ≈øhould be v≈øed like ≈ølaues by euery ≈ølaue.
And notwith≈øtanding their Con≈øuls and Amba≈ø≈øadours too, yet they are oftentimes abu≈øed by Turks both in words and deeds.

In words they reuile them as the Egyptians did the I≈øraelites, and call them Gours, that is, Infidels: and Cupec, that is, dog: and Canzier, that is, Hogge: and by many other odious and reproachfull names. And though they ≈øtrike them, yet dare they not ≈øtrike againe le≈øt they loo≈øe their hand, or be wor≈øe v≈øed.

They al≈øo oftentimes make Auenias of them, that is, fal≈øe accu≈øations; and ≈øuborne fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øes to confirme it to bee true: and no Chri≈øtians word will bee take again≈øt a Turke, for they account vs infidels, and call them≈øelues Mu≈ø≈øelmen, that is, True bel√©euers.

This mi≈øerie abroad will make bs loue our owne Contrie the better when wee come thither. And that is the be≈øt le≈ø≈øon which I haue learned in my trauels, Mundi contemptum, that is, The contempt of the world. And S. Pauls le≈ø≈øon, Phil. 4. 11. In what≈øoeuer ≈øtate I am, therewith to be content.

Oh how happie are you in England if you knew your own happine≈ø≈øe? But as the prodigall ≈øonne vntill he was pinched with penurie abroad, neuer con≈øidered the plentie of his fathers hou≈øe: So many in England know not their own felicitie, becau≈øe they doe not know the mi≈øeries of others.

But if they were here in this heathen Countrie, they would know what it is to liue in a Chri≈øtian common wealth, vnder the gouernement of a godly king, who ruleth by Law and not by lu≈øt; where there is plentie and peace, and preaching of the Go≈øpell, and manie other godly ble≈ø≈øings, which others want.
And God long continue his mercies to our noble King Iames, and his whole Realmes, and giue vs grace as farre to excell other Nations in thankfulne≈ø≈øe as we doe in happine≈ø≈øe.

And thus for pre≈øent I commend you to the mo≈øt gracious protection of the Almightie IEHOVAH, be≈ø√©eching him, (if it be his will) to ≈øend vs a ioyfull m√©eting, both in this world, and in the world to come. Amen.

The Turkes, Moores, Arabians, and other Mahometans, neuer remooue for feare of any ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, nor refu≈øe any mans company infected therewith; for they ≈øay euery mans fortune is written in his forehead, and that they ≈øhall not die before their time; not knowing what it is to tempt God, and to refu≈øe ordinarie meanes. But in this interim, from the beginning of this ≈øickne≈ø≈øe (which was in March) vntill the expected and vndoubted end, when the Sunne entereth into Leo, we who≈øe names are ≈øub≈øcribed (for cau≈øes aboue mentioned) tooke our voyage from Aleppo towards Ieru≈øalem, hauing letters of commendation from Clari≈ø≈øimo Imo the Venice Con≈øul, and ≈øundry others of the chiefs Italian Merchants, to their Padres at Ieru≈øalem, for our kinde v≈øage there, with liberty of con≈øcience.

Anno Dom. 1600. March 9. after dinner we ≈øet foorth, guarded with Iene≈øaries, and accompanied with ≈øundry Engli≈øh, Italian, and French Merchants, who in kindne≈ø≈øe rode with vs ≈øeuen or eight miles, to bring vs on the way, and then returned to Aleppo. When the day appeared,Saracoope. our way was plea≈øant and comfortable vnto vs, vntill we came to a village called Saracoope, whither we came about noone, March. 10. March. 11. betimes in the morning we departed froÃÑ Saracoop, and came betimes in the afternoone to a fine Village called Marrah, Marrah. where there is a very faire new Cane builded by Amrath (commonly called Morat) Chillabee, ≈øometimes Defterdare, that is, Trea≈øurer of Aleppo, and afterwards of Dama≈øcus, who for the refuge of trauellers, & their protection again≈øt th√©eues, built a ≈øtately ≈øtrong Cane like vnto Leaden-Hall in London, or rather the Exchance in London, where there are faire vpper

The ≈øhower cea≈øing, we rode from this Chappell and village of Lacke money (I ≈øhould haue ≈øaid Lacmin, but might ≈øay, lacke men and money too) and rode forward vntill we came vnto a village or towne called Tyaba, where (becau≈øe it was neere night) we de≈øired to lodge, but could not be admitted into any hou≈øe for any money, whereupon our chiefe Iene≈øarie Byram B ‚Ä¢ ≈øhaw went into an hou≈øe, and offred to pull man, woman, and childe out of the hou≈øe, that we might bring in our hor≈øes, and lodge there our ≈øelues. div.head: Of Dama≈øcus.
div.p: DAma≈øcus is a mo≈øt ancient City, and as E≈øay ≈øpake of it in his time, The head of Aram is Dama≈øcus: I≈øa. 7. 8. ≈øo Dama≈øcus is the chiefe≈øt City of Syria to this day. The ≈øituation thereof is mo≈øt plea≈øant, being built on a plaine ground, ≈øtrongly walled about, and a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle therein, with many fine riuers running on euery ≈øide of it, e≈øpecially Abanah and Pharpar, mentioned 2. There is a fine towne n√©ere vnto Dama≈øcus, about two or thr√©e miles di≈øtant on the ≈øide of an hill,Salhia. called Salhia, from whence a man may behold the pro≈øpect of the Citie of Dama≈øcus mo≈øt plea≈øantly, with the gardens and plea≈øant places about it.

At Dama≈øcus we met many thou≈øand Turkes going on Pilgrimage towards Mecha in Arabia to vi≈øit Mahomets ≈øepulchre, as they v≈øually doe euery y√©ere about their Byram time; for they hold that who≈øoeuer once in his life time ≈øhall not goe on Pilgrimage to Mecha, to ≈ø√©e the ≈øepulcher of their Prophet, ≈øhall neuer enter into Paradi≈øe. And it is forbidden to all Chri≈øtians vpon paine of death to come n√©ere Mecha within fiue miles: partly, le≈øt they ≈øhould marre their markets; but chiefly, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øee their folly
