div.p: And who≈øoeuer (≈øay they) dieth in his pilgrimage thither, or returning from thence, is ≈øure to goe to Heauen pre≈øently. And they that haue b√©ene there but once, are alwaies after called Hogies, Hogies. that is, Pilgrimes: and are called by that name in this manner.

If his name before were Mahomet, he is at his returne called Hogie Mahomet. If before Mu≈øtapha, he is alwaies after called Hogie Mu≈øtapha, &c. And they that haue b√©ene often at Mecha and returne againe, are called great Hogies. And euery y√©ere when the Carauan of Pilgrimes returneth from Mecha, he that hath b√©ene there oftne≈øt is called The great Hogie: and is greatly honoured of them all, for he rideth before them all in more ≈øtately apparell then they, with flowers and garlands about his hor≈øe, and when they come n√©ere any great Citie, the chiefe≈øt men in the citie ride foorth to m√©et him, and bring him into the Citie with great ≈øolemnitie.

They fal≈øly affirme that this their Temple at Mecha in Arabia was built by Abraham, and they prepare them≈øelues with greater care to goe to wor≈øhip there, then many Chri≈øtians do when they come to the Lords Supper; for they di≈øburden their hearts of all hatred and malice, and reconcile them≈øelues one to another, &c. Otherwi≈øe they hold that all their labour is lo≈øt, and that they ≈øhalbe neuer a whit the better for their Pilgrimage. But if they forgiue one another, and repent them for their former ≈øinnes, they thinke there to obtaine ful remi≈ø≈øion of all their ≈øinnes, and that at their returne they are pure and without ≈øpot.

March 22. We rode before the re≈øt of the company. Our way that we trauelled all this day was exceeding bad, rocky, watri≈øh,Arabia Petr ‚Ä¢ a. and barren, called Arabia Pet ‚Ä¢ ea, where our hor≈øes often times ≈øtucke fa≈øt in the puddles and miry places, and ≈øometimes ready to breake their owne legs, and their Riders necks among rocks and ≈øtones. It was neither plea≈øant going on foot, nor riding this way, for there was no path nor euen ground, but huge ≈øtones and rocks ≈øo n√©ere together, that our hor≈øes could goe but a foot pace, and often times met with ≈øuch mari≈øhes and quagmires, that we were con≈øtrained to goe farre about before we could finde better waies to pa≈ø≈øe ouer. It is al≈øo exceeding cold in this place alwaies (in re≈øpect of other places in that Country) for there are neither tr√©es, nor hou≈øes, nor high hils to keepe away the violence and force of the winds. The Carauans that trauel v≈øually that way betwixt Dama≈øcus and Egypt, ≈øay that this daies iourney troubleth them more than all the re≈øt, and that they neuer pa≈ø≈øe by that way, but they leaue two or three of their Cammels behinde them, ≈øome mi≈øfortune or other befalling vnto them. We ≈øaw al≈øo in ≈øundrie
places this way, the carca≈øes of many dead cammels which haue mi≈øcarried among≈øt the rocks. It is al≈øo a very th√©eui≈øh way, full of wilde Arabs: yet (by the prouidence of God) wee came ≈øafely that day to Conetra, where we lodged in a good Cane, di≈øtant from Sa≈ø≈øa 28. miles.

After our tedious trauell to Conetra, finding the place plea≈øant at our comming thither, we walked about to ≈øolace our ≈øelues in beholding the gr√©ene pa≈øtures and running riuers nere vnto it, and in viewing the order of ≈øundry Nations there a≈ø≈øembled together from ≈øundry places. Some comming from Egypt, and bound to Dama≈øcus, pitched their tents without the Cane, n√©ere vnto the riuer. Others comming from Dama≈øcus, and bound to Ieru≈øalem, accommodated them≈øelues (in ≈øuch ≈øort as they could) within the Cane. But e≈øpecially in a Bazar (like vnto a cloi≈øter) adioining to the Cane, wee tooke plea≈øure to walke vp and downe ≈øome few turns, which the Turks beholding, wondred at vs: (for it is not their cu≈øtome in tho≈øe hot Countries to walke vp and downe as we doe in cold Countries, but to ≈øit ≈øtill on the ground like brute bea≈øts) and one of them came vnto vs, and a≈øked vs what we meant to walke vp and downe in ≈øuch ≈øort, and whether we were out of our way, or out of our wits. If your way (≈øaid he) lieth toward the vpper end of the cloi≈øter, why come you downwards? And if at the netherend, why goe you backe againe? We an≈øwered him, For our plea≈øure. He replied, that it was greater plea≈øure to ≈øit ≈øtill, than to walke vp and downe when we n√©ed not. But their bruti≈øh ≈øitting ≈øtil on the ground was as ≈øtrange vnto vs, as our walking vp and downe was to them.

It ≈ø√©emed no le≈ø≈øe ≈øtrange vnto them to ≈ø√©e a Chri≈øtian with a cut dublet: and they called him foole, and a≈øked him what h√©e meant to make holes in his coat: for they neither cut nor pinke any of their garments, but weare them all plaine, ≈øparing for no co≈øt to guard them with lace of ≈øiluer and gold if they be able.

And ≈øuch as weare long haire on their heads, the Turkes call ≈ølouens, and account them ≈øauage bea≈øts; for they them≈øelues weare no haire on their heads at all, but ≈øhaue them euery w√©eke once, and k√©epe them warme with a Turbant of white
≈øha≈øh made of cotten woole, which they neuer vncouer in their ≈øalutations to any man, but bow their heads, with their hands on their brea≈øts.

But if a man haue a faire long beard, they reuerence him, and ≈øay he is a wi≈øe man, and an honourable per≈øonage. But if they haue no beards at all, they call them (if they be yoong) Barda≈ø≈øes, that is Sodomiticall boies. But if they be men growen, and haue no beards, they call them fooles, and men of no credit; and ≈øome of them refu≈øe to buy or ≈øell with ≈øuch, and ≈øay they haue no wit, and that they will not bel√©eue them, &c.

March 23. We had a more plea≈øant way; for the fir≈øt ten miles w√©e rode thorow the fields and a very plea≈øant Parke. But when w√©e came out of this Parke or Fore≈øt, wee were ≈øomewhat troubled, partly by rea≈øon of the bad way, and partlie by bad people in the way. The way was ≈øtony and rockie (as the former daies iourney was) but yet dry, and not long, for it was but the de≈øcending downe a rockie hill, where though the way were dangerous vnder our f√©et, yet it was plea≈øant before our faces, for w√©e beheld the pro≈øpect of part of the holy Land, viz. Galile.

But at our de≈øending downe this mountaine, the people did more trouble vs then the way; for there ≈øate among≈øt the rocks in our way many Turks and Arabs, with maces of Iron and other weapons, who ≈øtaied vs and demanded Caphar or tole money; we were glad to giue them content that w√©e might pa≈ø≈øe ≈øafely by them, as Iacob was glad to ≈øend his brother E≈øau gifts, for a Ne noceat (as the Lawyers ≈øpeake) that is, for feare of danger.

But the Carauan of Chri≈øtians, who came after vs, though they were many hundreds, yet ≈øome of them being not able, ≈øome not willing to pay ≈øo much mony as they demanded, were ≈øhrewdly beaten with their iron ma≈øes. There was a Ie≈øuite in their company, who e≈øcaped not without ≈øtripes, whereat (as I haue heard) he reioiced, and counted it meritorious, in that he ≈øuffered ≈øuch mi≈øery in ≈øo holy a voyage. And in my hearing, at Ieru≈øalem one of his companions told him, that he merited much to ≈øu≈øteine ≈øuch trauell and labour, and be at ≈øo great
co≈øt and charges, and ≈øuffer ≈øo many ≈øtripes for Chri≈øts ≈øake: But I know, had it not b√©ene more for loue of his pur≈øe than for loue of Chri≈øt, he might haue e≈øcaped without ≈øtripes, yea with the≈øe kinde ≈øpeeches, Marhabbah Ianum, that is, Welcome my friend or ≈øweet-heart.

At another place in my trauels I heard a Friar bragging of his good workes, and ≈øaying, that h√©e had done ≈øo many good workes, that if he ≈øhould kill thr√©e men, his good works would make ≈øati≈øfaction, and merit remi≈ø≈øion for them all. To whom one in my company an≈øwered, that by his murder he might merit ind√©ed a double reward, viz. death in this life, and damnation in the life to come, for blood will haue blood; For who≈øoeuer ≈øheddeth mans blood, by man ≈øhall his blood be ≈øhed. But to let pa≈ø≈øe the≈øe Ie≈øuiticall Iebu≈øites, or Iebu≈øiticall Ie≈øuites: In that the≈øe trauellers were thus beaten for ≈øparing their pur≈øes, and though they were many hundreds, dur≈øt not ≈øtrike them againe,An admonition for Trauellers. h√©ere I may fitly take occa≈øion to teach tho≈øe that purpo≈øe to trauell into Turkey, how to behaue them≈øelues. If they be ≈øet vpon by th√©eues, they may defend them≈øelues in their trauels, if they be ≈øtrong enough; but if they be poling officers (as the≈øe were) they mu≈øt not be contradicted. But neither in their Cities, nor in their trauels, may they ≈øtrike againe though they be abu≈øed and beaten by any man (except they be th√©eues and robbers) for if they doe, they ≈øhall either be put to death, or haue their hand cut off. Neither if a man receiue a box on the eare at any of their hands, mu≈øt he giue one bad word, or looke frowningly vpon him that ≈ømote him: for then he will ≈øtrike him againe, and ≈øay, What, Goure? Doe≈øt thou cur≈øe me, and wi≈øh that the Deuill had me? But he mu≈øt ki≈ø≈øe his beard, or the ≈økirt of his garment, and ≈ømile vpon him, and then he will let him pa≈ø≈øe.
Wherefore, trauellers into tho≈øe parts mu≈øt looke vpon the picture of a ≈øeruant as of old he was wont to be painted, that thereby they may learne how to behaue them≈øelues in trauell.

I read, that of old they were wont to paint the picture of a ≈øeruant at the doores of their hou≈øes, that their ≈øeruants might ≈ø√©e how they ≈øhould behaue them≈øelues. And he was painted on
this manner; With the ≈ønout of a Swine, the eares of an A≈ø≈øe, the feet of an Hart, with hands open, with his garments cleanly, and on his head a bonnet, hauing on his backe a coule≈øtaffe, with two ve≈ø≈øels, the one hauing in it fire, the other water.
This de≈øcription, though it be rude and homely, yet it teacheth plainly ≈øeruants and trauellers their duties.
The Swines ≈ønout declareth that they mu≈øt not be daintie mouthed, but mu≈øt be content with any meat which God hath prouided for man.
The A≈ø≈øes eares, that they mu≈øt patiently heare the ≈øharpe ≈øpeeches of their Ma≈øters, without an≈øwering againe.
The Harts f√©et, that they mu≈øt be ≈øwift in doing their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Their Hands wide open, that they mu≈øt be faithfull, not deceitfull: They mu≈øt doe nothing clo≈øely or ≈øecretly: They mu≈øt haue their che≈øts, their hands, their hearts open to their Ma≈øters eie and commandement, when it plea≈øeth him to call them to account.
Their garments comely and hone≈øt, which their bonnet declares, that they mu≈øt not be ≈ølouenly, but hand≈øome and ≈ø√©emly apparelled, and yet not proudly aboue their degr√©es.
The coule≈øtaffe on their ≈øhoulder, that they mu≈øt not refu≈øe to doe any worke, no not to carry water.
And the fire and water, the one before them, and the other behinde, ≈øheweth their di≈øcretion in their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: They mu≈øt not mingle fire and water together.

Mo≈øt of the≈øe qualities are required in Trauellers. In diet they mu≈øt not be dainty, but eat what they can get. Their eares mu≈øt not be nice, for they ≈øhall heare ≈øpeeches enough to offend them. Their f√©et mu≈øt be ≈øwift to flie from dangers: Their hands wide open to giue liberally: Their apparell al≈øo mu≈øt be neat in Cities where they ≈øoiourne, for their credit: But when they trauell abroad, it mu≈øt be ≈øimple, for their ≈øafety: for the ba≈øer their apparell is, the better ≈øhall they pa≈ø≈øe: for if they weare good apparell, their throats will be cut for their apparell, and hope of much money: for tho≈øe that go braue they account rich. And whereas in ≈øeruants it is commendable
to haue a≈ø≈øes eares; in trauellers it is n√©edfull to haue a≈ø≈øes backes al≈øo, to beare all abu≈øes in good part, and rather to beare an hundreth abu≈øes then to offer one.
Wherfore ≈øeruants and trauellers mu≈øt alwaies remember this Di≈øtichon, or couple of ver≈øes following.

q.l: Nobile vincendi genus e≈øt patientia, vincit
Qui patitur: ≈øivis vincere, di≈øcepati:

div.p: that is,

q.l: A noble kind of conquering
is patience to ≈øee and heare:
He which forbeareth, conquereth,
If thou wilt conquer, learne to beare.

div.p: But to leaue the≈øe matters, and to proc√©ede to my voiage. At the foote of this mountaine there is an old Cane where v≈øually trauellers lodge: but it b√©eing not yet noone, we re≈øolued to trauell 18 miles further, to the Sea of Galile. At the foote of this ≈øtony hill, hard by this Cane, there runneth a plea≈øant riuer, which diuideth Siria from Galile. And ouer this riuer there is a fair bridge, the one end whereof is out of the holy land, the other in it. This riuer is called Iordane, Iordan. the head whereof commeth from Mount Libanus, and maketh three Seas.
The fir≈øt is the waters of Maron which wee left on our right hand, about ten miles off. The other on the left hand, which lay in our waie as we ≈øhould trauell.
The ≈øecond is the ≈øea of Galile, or Tiberias, or lake of Genezereth.
The third is the Sea of Sodome, called Mare mortuum, where the riuer Iordan endeth.
The bridge that cro≈ø≈øeth this Riuer Iordan at the entrance into the holy land, is called Iacobs bridge; for two cau≈øes.
Fir≈øt, it is ≈øaid that there Iacob met his brother E≈øau.
Secondly, that there Iacob wre≈øtled with an Angel.

div.head: A de≈øcription of the Holy Land.
div.p:
THE whole Holy Land of old was called Chanaan, and it was deuided into thr√©e parts, viz. Galile, Iudea & Pale ‚Ä¢ tina. Later writers haue called all by the name of Pale≈øtina. The fir≈øt
part of Canaan called Galile, Iacobs bridge. beginneth at this bridge, and to this day it is a very plea≈øant and fruitful Countrie. After wee were entred into Galile about 2. miles from the bridge, our Iene≈øarie a≈øked vs whether we would go vp to a mountaine, and ≈øo to Saphetta neere vnto mount Carmel, which is a place of leaning for Iewes; or keepe the lower way, and goe by the ≈øea of Galile, which is the plea≈øanter way: and thereof we made choi≈øe; and tooke Saphetta in our way afterwards.

About ≈øeuen miles from Iacobs bridge, our guide brought vs to a well, adorned with marble pillers, and couered with ≈øtone, which he ≈øaid to haue beene the pit whereinto Io≈øeph was put when his brethren ≈øold him to the I≈øhmalites. But it ≈øeemed to vs incredible: fir≈øt, becau≈øe that was a dry pit, and this is ful of ≈øweet water.

Againe, Iacob dwelt at Hebron twelue miles beyond Ieru≈øalem, and his ≈øonnes kept ≈øh√©epe in Shechem. And that dry pit whereinto they put Io≈øeph was at Dothan (which we ≈øaw afterwards) And this pit which they ≈øhewed vs with marble pillars, was in Galile; not n√©ere Dothan nor Shechem where Io≈øephs brethren kept their fathers ≈øheepe.

But by others of better iudgement wee vnder≈øtood that this al≈øo was called Io≈øeps pit, or well, becau≈øe it was built by one Io≈øph, not Io≈øeph the ≈øonne of Iacob, but ≈øome other. But the ignorant people which trauell that way, are apt to beleeue any things that is told them. About ten miles from this well, we came to a Cane called by the Moores Minium, but by the Turkes Mi≈ø≈øia, hard by the ≈øea of Galile, where we lodged all night, hauing trauelled that day by computation 36. miles.

The foure and twentieth of March we rode along by the Sea of Galile, which, Iohn 6. 1. is called by two mames, viz. the Sea of Galile or Tiberias. Galile, Galile. becau≈øe it is in Galile: and Tiberias, becau≈øe the City Tiberias was built by it, and Beth≈øaida an other ancient City; of both which we ≈øaw ≈øome ruinous Wals. And it is ≈øaid in that Chapter (Iohn 6. 1.) that Ie≈øus went ouer the Sea of Galile: and in an other place that he went beyond the Lake. And Luke 9. 10. It is ≈øaid, that h√©e went into a ≈ølitary place, neere vnto a Citie called Beth≈øaida, which
place of Iohn I learned to vnder≈øtand better by ≈øeeing it, then euer I could before by reading of it. For, ≈ø√©eing that Tiberias and Beth≈øaida were both Cities on the ≈øame ≈øide of the Sea, and Chri≈øt went from Tiberias too, or neere vnto Beth≈øaida; I gather thereby that our Sauiour Chri≈øt went not ouer the length or breadth of that Sea; but ouer ≈øome Arme, bo≈øome or reach thereof, viz. ≈øo farre as Tiberias was di≈øtant from Beth≈øaida; which is al≈øo confirmed in that it is ≈øaid el≈øwhere, A great multitude followed him on foot thither; which they could not haue done if he had gone quite ouer the Sea, to the other ≈øide among the Gergelens, which is out of the holy Land. And therfore this Sea of Galile, is al≈øo called the Lake of Gene≈øereth, becau≈øe the Countrey of the Cerge≈øens is on the other ≈øide the Lake, from whence the Swine ran headlong into the Sea and were choaked therein: and as that place was out of the holy Land; ≈øo the people which then inhabited it, were as far from holines, when they reque≈øted our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt to depart out of their Coa≈øts. And ≈øuch like holy people inhabite there ≈øtill, viz. wild Arabs, and Turks, &c. We ≈øawe al≈øo (neere vnto this Sea) the place where that Towne (mentioned Iohn 2. 1. called Cana of Galile ≈øtood, where our Sauiour Chri≈øt at a mariage turned water into wine; in place whereof there ≈øtandeth now a poore village inhabited by Turks.

This ≈øea of Galile is (by computation) in length 8. leagues, and in breadth 5. leagues, and euery league is thr√©e miles; and then it enclo≈øeth it ≈øelfe into a narrowe compa≈ø≈øe, carrying but the breadth of an ordinarie riuer vntill it come to Sodome, where it endeth, which is called mare mortuum, that is, The dead Sea.
After we had rode about ≈øeuen miles by the ≈øea of Galile, we left it on our left hand, and a≈øcended vp a mountaine on the right hand.

This mountaine was not very ≈øt√©epie, but exc√©eding plea≈øant and fertile, for (being the ≈øpringtime) it was ≈øo be≈øet with ≈øuch varietie of flowers among the greene gra≈ø≈øe, that they ≈ø√©emed to flire in our faces, and to laugh and ≈øing (as the P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øpeaketh) as we went. P≈øal. 65. 13.
This is ≈øaid to bee that mountaine mentioned John 6. 9. where our Sauiour Chri≈øt wrought a miracle in feeding 5000. men with fiue Barley loaues, and two fi≈øhes.

When we came to the top of the mountaine, we ≈øaw Saphetta on the right hand, a Vniuer≈øitie of the Iewes where they ≈øpeake Hebrew, and haue their Synagogues there. The Citie Saphet ‚Ä¢ a is ≈øituated on a very high hill with thr√©e tops, and ≈øo the Citie h ‚Ä¢ th three parts; one part is inhabited by Iewes, the other two by Tu ‚Ä¢ kes. We a≈øked ≈øome Iewes whom we knew formerly to haue b√©ene Merchants of Aleppo, what they meant to leaue their trade and to liue there: They an≈øwered, they were now olde and came thither to die, that they might b√©e n√©erer to heauen: wee told them, that how≈øoeuer they might ≈øeeme there to bee n√©erer to heauen whiles they lined, becau≈øe they dwelt on an high mountaine, yet that they ≈øhould not bee n√©erer vnto heauen when they died, vnle≈ø≈øe they repented and bel√©eued in Chri≈øt, &c. The Iewes haue here more libertie then in any part of the holy land. They dare not come to Ieru≈øalem for feare le≈øt the Chri≈øtians there dwelling, ≈øtone them.

Whiles wee were at Saphetta, many Turkes departed from thence towards Mecha in Arabia. And the ≈øame morning they went, we ≈øaw many women playing with Tymbrels as they went along the ≈øtr√©ete, and made a yelling or ≈øcriking noi≈øe as though they cryed. We a≈øked what they meant in ≈øo doing? It was an≈øwered vs, that they mourned for the departure of their hu≈øbands, who were gone that morning on ‚Ä¢ ilgrimage to Mecha, and they feared that they ≈øhould neuer ≈ø√©e them again, becau≈øe it was a long way and dangerous, and many died there euery y√©ere. It ≈ø√©emed ≈øtrange to vs, that they ≈øhould mourne with mu≈øicke about the ≈øtr√©etes, for mu≈øicke is v≈øed in other places at times of mirth, and not at times of mourning. But they did it but Paruae con≈øuetudmis cau≈øa. For a litle cu≈øtomes ≈øake. And I doubt not but many of them were glad for their departure, and would be glader if they would neuer come againe, they v≈øe them ≈øo kindly.

And vnder pretence of deuotion, many trauell to Mecha to buy their Indian and Per≈øian commodities: for many of them
≈øee their palpaple ignorance, and in ≈øecret ≈øpeake again≈øt it to tho≈øe with whom they may be bold, and ≈øay, their religion is naught, yet (being merchants) to auoid pouertie they trauell thither among≈øt the re≈øt. So true is that common and commendable ≈øaying:

q.l: Impiger, ex tremos, currit mercator ad Indos:
Per mare, pauperiem fugiens, per ≈øaxa, per ignes.

div.p: that is,

q.l: The Merchant man though ≈ølowe of ≈øoote,
To th'Indian ≈øhoare doeth runne:
By ≈øea, by land, by fire, by ≈øword,
That pouertie he may ≈øhunne.

div.p: Yea there was one of their chiefe learned men in Con≈øtantinople, Anno Dom. 1604. ≈øpake again≈øt their Alcoran, which is the booke of all their religion, but he lo≈øt his head for his labor, which he willingly and ch√©erefully yeelded vnto them.

All the way which we trauelled this day, was very plea≈øant; and all the ground both hils and dales very fruitfull, according as it is de≈øcribed by Mo≈øes. Deut. 8. 7. 8. and Deut. 11. 10 and, 11. And we came that day, about two of the clock in the afternoone to a village called in the Arabick tongue J-nel Tyger, I-nel Tyger. that is (by interpretation) The Marehants eye, wherein there are two very faire Ca≈øtles for trauellers to lodge in from danger of wilde Arabs, which abound in tho≈øe parts: we tooke vp our lodging in the n√©ere≈øt ca≈øtle which is the faire≈øt.

After wee had refre≈øhed our ≈øelues,Tabor. and ≈ølept a while: beeing hard by mount Tabor, we de≈øired to a≈øcend to the top of it, and ≈øo much the rather becau≈øe I had read that the Papi≈øts to prooue the primacie, or ≈øupremacie of Peter aboue the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, alledge this for one argument, after that Chri≈øt was tran≈øfigured vpon mount Tabor (as we read Matth. 17. 1. 2. &c.) and there appeared to them, Mo≈øes, and Elias, talking with him, Peter ≈øaid to Ie≈øus, Ma≈øter, It is good for vs to bee heere, Let vs make heere three Tabernacles, one for thee, and one for Mo≈øes, and one for Elias. But of the Temple it is true which our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt ≈øpake Luk. 21. 6. For when as the Prophets denounced Gods iudgements vnto the Iewes, vnle≈ø≈øe they repented, they flattered them≈øelues in their ≈øinnes, and cried, Templum Domini, Templum Domini, The Temple of the Lord, The Temple of thy Lord.
